name: Fever (Pyrexia)
description: Fever is a temporary increase in body temperature, typically in response to an illness or infection. It is one of the body's natural defense mechanisms, as a higher temperature can help kill off temperature-sensitive bacteria and viruses. In India, fever is a primary symptom for many prevalent diseases like the flu, dengue, malaria, and typhoid. While usually a sign of a healthy immune response, a very high or persistent fever, especially in children and the elderly, can be uncomfortable and warrants medical attention to diagnose the underlying cause.
symptoms: Elevated body temperature (generally above 99.5°F or 37.5°C)
Sweating, shivering, or feeling chills
Headache and body aches
Loss of appetite and general weakness
Dehydration and flushed skin
Irritability or lethargy
prevention: Prevent underlying infections through frequent handwashing
Get recommended vaccinations for flu and other diseases
Avoid close contact with individuals who are sick
Maintain a strong immune system with a healthy diet, exercise, and adequate sleep
treatment: Get plenty of rest to allow the body to recover
Stay hydrated by drinking water, soups, or an oral rehydration solution (ORS)
Take over-the-counter fever reducers like Paracetamol or Ibuprofen
Wear light clothing and use a light blanket to avoid overheating
Consult a doctor if fever is very high (>103°F), lasts more than 3 days, or is accompanied by severe symptoms like confusion or difficulty breathing

name: Common Cold
description: The common cold is a mild viral infection of the nose and throat (upper respiratory tract). It is extremely common and is primarily caused by rhinoviruses. Colds are highly contagious and spread through airborne droplets when someone with the infection coughs, sneezes, or talks. Symptoms typically appear one to three days after exposure to the virus and usually resolve on their own within a week to ten days. There is no cure, so treatment focuses on relieving symptoms.
symptoms: Runny or stuffy nose (nasal congestion)
Sneezing and sore throat
Coughing and post-nasal drip
Watery eyes
Mild headache or body aches
Low-grade fever
prevention: Wash hands frequently with soap and water
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands
Stay away from people who are sick
Disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects
treatment: Symptomatic relief is key: rest and stay hydrated
Use saline nasal sprays or drops to relieve congestion
Over-the-counter pain relievers or cold medications can help with aches and fever
Gargling with warm salt water can soothe a sore throat
Use a humidifier to add moisture to the air

name: Cough
description: A cough is a reflex action to clear your airways of mucus and irritants such as dust or smoke. It is not a disease in itself but a symptom of an underlying condition. An occasional cough is normal and healthy. However, a persistent cough can indicate a medical problem, such as a respiratory tract infection, allergies, or chronic lung disease. Coughs can be dry (non-productive) or chesty (productive, bringing up phlegm).
symptoms: A sudden, forceful expulsion of air from the lungs
May be accompanied by phlegm or mucus (productive cough)
May be dry and hacking (non-productive cough)
Can be associated with a sore throat, chest discomfort, or shortness of breath
prevention: Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke
Prevent respiratory infections through good hygiene
Stay hydrated to keep the throat moist
Use a humidifier in dry environments
treatment: Drink plenty of warm fluids like herbal tea with honey or soups
Suck on lozenges or hard candies to soothe the throat
Use over-the-counter cough syrups (expectorants for chesty coughs, suppressants for dry coughs)
Steam inhalation can help loosen mucus
See a doctor if the cough lasts more than three weeks or is accompanied by high fever, blood, or difficulty breathing

name: Sore Throat (Pharyngitis)
description: A sore throat is pain, scratchiness, or irritation of the throat that often worsens when you swallow. The most common cause is a viral infection, such as a cold or the flu. A bacterial infection, like streptococcus (strep throat), is another common cause but is less frequent. Other causes include allergies, dry air, and irritants like smoke or pollution. Most sore throats are not serious and get better on their own within a week.
symptoms: Pain or a scratchy sensation in the throat
Pain that worsens with swallowing or talking
Difficulty swallowing
Red and swollen tonsils
A hoarse or muffled voice
Swollen glands in the neck or jaw
prevention: Practice good hygiene, especially handwashing
Avoid sharing food, drinks, and utensils
Avoid close contact with people who are sick
Avoid irritants like smoke and chemical fumes
treatment: Gargle with warm salt water several times a day
Drink warm liquids like tea with honey or clear broth
Suck on throat lozenges or ice chips
Use a humidifier to moisten the air
Rest your voice
For severe pain, use over-the-counter pain relievers. See a doctor if it's severe, persists, or you suspect strep throat

name: Headache / Migraine
description: A headache is a pain in any region of the head, ranging from sharp to dull, that may occur on one or both sides. A migraine is a type of headache that can cause severe throbbing pain, usually on one side of the head, and is often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Common headache triggers include stress, dehydration, lack of sleep, and certain foods. While most headaches are harmless, frequent or severe ones can significantly impact daily life.
symptoms: Headache: Dull, aching head pain; a sensation of tightness or pressure across the forehead or on the sides and back of the head.
Migraine: Intense throbbing or pulsing sensation, often on one side; nausea and vomiting; sensitivity to light (photophobia) and sound (phonophobia); visual disturbances (aura).
prevention: Stay hydrated and eat regular meals
Get enough sleep on a consistent schedule
Manage stress through relaxation techniques like yoga or meditation
Identify and avoid personal triggers (e.g., certain foods, strong smells)
Limit caffeine and alcohol intake
treatment: For headaches: Over-the-counter pain relievers like paracetamol, ibuprofen, or aspirin; rest in a quiet, dark room; apply a cold compress to the forehead.
For migraines: Specific migraine medications (triptans); rest in a dark, quiet room; caffeine in small amounts can help.
Consult a doctor for chronic or severe headaches/migraines

name: Stomach Pain & Indigestion (Dyspepsia)
description: Stomach pain (abdominal pain) is discomfort anywhere in the belly area. Indigestion, also known as dyspepsia or upset stomach, is a general term for discomfort in the upper abdomen. It often occurs after eating and can manifest as a burning sensation, bloating, or gassiness. Common causes include overeating, eating too quickly, consuming spicy or fatty foods, stress, and conditions like gastritis or acidity (GERD). Most cases are mild and can be managed with lifestyle changes and simple remedies.
symptoms: Dull, sharp, or cramping pain in the abdomen
Burning sensation in the upper stomach or chest (heartburn/acidity)
Bloating and a feeling of fullness
Excessive gas (burping or flatulence)
Nausea or rumbling in the stomach
prevention: Eat smaller, more frequent meals
Avoid trigger foods like spicy, fried, or acidic items
Eat slowly and chew food thoroughly
Avoid lying down immediately after eating
Manage stress and limit alcohol and caffeine
treatment: Over-the-counter antacids to neutralize stomach acid
Herbal remedies like ginger tea or mint (pudina) can help
Avoid solid foods for a few hours if pain is severe
Apply a warm compress to the abdomen
See a doctor if pain is severe, persistent, or accompanied by fever, vomiting blood, or bloody stools

name: Diarrhea
description: Diarrhea is characterized by loose, watery stools or a frequent need to have a bowel movement. It is a common problem that usually lasts a day or two and goes away on its own. It occurs when the lining of the intestine is unable to absorb fluid, or it actively secretes fluid. The most common causes are viral or bacterial infections, often from contaminated food or water ('food poisoning'). It can lead to significant fluid loss and dehydration, which is a major concern, especially for children.
symptoms: Frequent loose, watery stools (three or more times a day)
Abdominal cramps or pain
Bloating and nausea
An urgent feeling that you need to have a bowel movement
May be accompanied by fever or vomiting
prevention: Practice strict hand hygiene, especially before eating and after using the toilet
Consume safe, clean drinking water and properly cooked food
Avoid unpasteurized dairy products and raw meat or seafood
Be cautious with street food, especially during monsoon season in India
treatment: The primary goal is to prevent dehydration. Drink plenty of fluids, especially oral rehydration solutions (ORS)
Eat bland, easy-to-digest foods like bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT diet)
Avoid dairy products, fatty foods, and caffeine
Probiotics (like in yogurt/curd) can help restore healthy gut bacteria
Consult a doctor if diarrhea is severe, contains blood, or lasts for more than a couple of days

name: Constipation
description: Constipation is a condition in which you may have fewer than three bowel movements a week; stools that are hard, dry, or lumpy; or stools that are difficult or painful to pass. It is a very common digestive issue. The most frequent causes include a low-fiber diet, dehydration, lack of physical activity, and ignoring the urge to have a bowel movement. While usually not serious, chronic constipation can be uncomfortable and affect quality of life.
symptoms: Infrequent bowel movements
Straining during bowel movements
Hard or small stools
A feeling that everything didn’t come out
Abdominal bloating or pain
prevention: Eat a high-fiber diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
Drink an adequate amount of water and other fluids throughout the day
Engage in regular physical activity
Don't ignore the urge to have a bowel movement
Establish a regular routine for bowel movements
treatment: Gradually increase dietary fiber intake
Increase fluid consumption
Regular exercise can stimulate intestinal activity
Over-the-counter fiber supplements or gentle laxatives can be used for short-term relief
Consult a doctor for chronic constipation or if accompanied by severe pain or bleeding

name: Vomiting and Nausea
description: Nausea is the sensation of an urge to vomit. Vomiting (emesis) is the forceful voluntary or involuntary emptying of stomach contents through the mouth. They are not diseases but symptoms of many different conditions, such as infections (food poisoning, gastroenteritis), motion sickness, pregnancy, or as a side effect of medication. They are the body's way of ridding itself of harmful substances. The main risk associated with vomiting is dehydration.
symptoms: Nausea: An unpleasant, queasy feeling in the stomach.
Vomiting: The act of throwing up stomach contents.
May be accompanied by sweating, dizziness, and abdominal pain.
prevention: Avoid known triggers like certain foods, smells, or motion
Eat small, frequent meals instead of large ones
Avoid spicy, greasy, or hard-to-digest foods
Practice good food hygiene to prevent food poisoning
treatment: Rest the stomach by avoiding solid food for a few hours
Prevent dehydration by sipping small amounts of clear fluids (water, ORS, clear broth) frequently
Gradually reintroduce bland foods as you feel better
Ginger (as tea or candy) is a common home remedy for nausea
Over-the-counter antiemetic medications may help
Seek medical help if vomiting is severe, persistent, contains blood, or is accompanied by high fever or severe pain

name: Body and Muscle Pain (Myalgia)
description: Body pain and muscle pain (myalgia) are extremely common and can range from mild to excruciating. They can be felt anywhere in the body. The most frequent causes are overuse or injury from exercise or physical work, tension, and stress. It is also a common symptom of systemic infections like the flu or other viral illnesses. Usually, muscle pain is localized to a specific area, while general body aches affect the whole body.
symptoms: Dull, aching, or sharp pain in muscles
Tenderness or soreness in the affected area
Pain that worsens with movement
Can be accompanied by weakness or fatigue
prevention: Warm up properly before exercise and cool down afterward
Stretch regularly to maintain flexibility
Stay hydrated, especially during physical activity
Avoid overexertion and lift heavy objects correctly
treatment: Rest the affected area
Apply ice for the first 24-48 hours to reduce inflammation, then switch to heat to improve blood flow
Take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or paracetamol
Gentle stretching and massage can help relieve tension
A warm bath with Epsom salts can soothe sore muscles

name: Back Pain
description: Back pain is a very common complaint, affecting millions of people. It can result from injury, activity, and some medical conditions. It can affect people of any age, for different reasons. Common causes include muscle or ligament strain from improper lifting or sudden awkward movements, poor posture, and age-related changes to the spine. While most back pain is short-lived (acute), some people experience long-term (chronic) pain.
symptoms: A muscle ache or dull pain in the lower or upper back
Shooting or stabbing pain
Pain that radiates down the leg (as in sciatica)
Limited flexibility or range of motion of the back
Pain that worsens with bending, lifting, standing, or walking
prevention: Engage in regular exercise to strengthen core and back muscles
Maintain a healthy weight to reduce strain on the back
Practice good posture when sitting and standing
Lift heavy objects correctly using your legs, not your back
Ensure your workstation is ergonomically set up
treatment: Apply heat or ice to the painful area
Use over-the-counter pain relievers
Continue light activity and gentle stretching as tolerated; avoid complete bed rest
Topical pain relief creams or gels can be effective
Seek medical advice if pain is severe, doesn't improve with rest, or is accompanied by numbness or weakness in the legs

name: Toothache and Gum Pain
description: A toothache is pain in or around a tooth. The most common cause is tooth decay (cavities), but it can also be caused by a cracked tooth, an abscess, gum disease, or a loose filling. Gum pain is often a sign of gingivitis or periodontitis (gum disease), caused by plaque buildup. The pain can range from mild to severe and may be constant or intermittent. It's important to see a dentist to determine the exact cause.
symptoms: Sharp, throbbing, or constant pain in a tooth
Pain when chewing or applying pressure
Sensitivity to hot or cold temperatures
Swelling around the tooth or in the gums
Red, tender, or bleeding gums
prevention: Brush your teeth twice a day with fluoride toothpaste and floss daily
Limit sugary foods and drinks
Visit a dentist regularly for checkups and cleanings
Avoid smoking and using tobacco products
treatment: Rinse your mouth with warm salt water
Take over-the-counter pain relievers
Applying clove oil (eugenol) to the affected tooth can provide temporary relief
Use a cold compress on the outside of your cheek
It is essential to see a dentist for proper diagnosis and treatment (e.g., filling, root canal, or cleaning)

name: Allergy
description: An allergy is an exaggerated response by the immune system to a substance that is normally harmless to most people. These substances are known as allergens and can include things like pollen, dust mites, pet dander, insect stings, certain foods, or medications. When a person with an allergy comes into contact with an allergen, their immune system releases chemicals like histamine, which cause allergy symptoms. Symptoms can range from mild sneezing to a life-threatening reaction known as anaphylaxis.
symptoms: Sneezing, runny or stuffy nose, and itchy, watery eyes (hay fever/allergic rhinitis)
Itchy skin, hives (urticaria), or eczema
Coughing, wheezing, or shortness of breath (asthma)
Swelling of the lips, tongue, or face
Stomach cramps, vomiting, or diarrhea (food allergies)
prevention: Identify and avoid your specific allergens
Keep windows closed during high pollen seasons
Use dust-proof covers on bedding and wash it in hot water to control dust mites
Keep your home clean and dry to prevent mold growth
Read food labels carefully if you have food allergies
treatment: Over-the-counter or prescription antihistamines to relieve sneezing, itching, and runny nose
Nasal corticosteroid sprays for nasal allergy symptoms
Decongestants for short-term relief of stuffiness
For severe allergies, a doctor might recommend allergy shots (immunotherapy) or an emergency epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen)

name: Acne / Pimples
description: Acne is a very common skin condition that occurs when hair follicles become plugged with oil (sebum) and dead skin cells. This can cause whiteheads, blackheads, or pimples. It is most common among teenagers, though it affects people of all ages. Factors like hormones, genetics, and certain medications can contribute to acne. While not dangerous, severe acne can cause emotional distress and lead to skin scarring.
symptoms: Whiteheads (closed plugged pores)
Blackheads (open plugged pores)
Small red, tender bumps (papules)
Pimples (pustules), which are papules with pus at their tips
Large, solid, painful lumps under the skin (nodules)
Painful, pus-filled lumps under the skin (cystic lesions)
prevention: Wash your face twice a day with a gentle cleanser
Use non-comedogenic (won't clog pores) makeup and skincare products
Avoid touching your face frequently
Shampoo your hair regularly, especially if it's oily
Maintain a balanced diet and manage stress
treatment: Over-the-counter topical treatments containing benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid
Prescription topical creams like retinoids or antibiotics
Oral antibiotics or hormonal therapy for moderate to severe acne
In severe cases, a dermatologist may prescribe isotretinoin
Avoid squeezing or picking pimples to prevent scarring

name: Eye Infection / Conjunctivitis
description: An eye infection occurs when harmful microorganisms—bacteria, fungi, or viruses—invade any part of the eyeball or surrounding area. The most common type is conjunctivitis, also known as 'red eye' or 'pink eye', which is an inflammation of the conjunctiva (the transparent membrane that lines the eyelid and covers the white part of the eyeball). It is often highly contagious and is very common in India, especially during season changes. Symptoms can vary but usually involve redness, itching, and discharge.
symptoms: Redness or pinkness in the white of the eye(s)
Itching, burning, or a gritty feeling in the eye
A discharge that forms a crust during the night (watery for viral, thick/yellow for bacterial)
Increased tear production (watery eyes)
Swelling of the eyelids
Sensitivity to light (photophobia)
prevention: Wash hands thoroughly and frequently
Avoid touching or rubbing your eyes
Do not share personal items like towels, pillows, or eye makeup
Clean eyeglasses and contact lenses properly
Protect eyes from dust and pollutants by wearing sunglasses
treatment: For viral conjunctivitis: It usually clears on its own; cool compresses can soothe the eye.
For bacterial conjunctivitis: A doctor will prescribe antibiotic eye drops or ointment.
For allergic conjunctivitis: Antihistamine eye drops can help.
Gently clean eyelids with a wet cloth
Stop wearing contact lenses until the infection is gone

name: Ear Pain / Ear Infection (Otitis)
description: Ear pain (otalgia) can be a sharp, dull, or burning pain in one or both ears. A common cause is an ear infection (otitis), which occurs when a bacterial or viral infection affects the middle, outer, or inner ear. Middle ear infections (otitis media) are very common in children and often follow a cold. Outer ear infections (otitis externa or swimmer's ear) can be caused by water remaining in the ear after swimming. The pain is due to inflammation and the buildup of fluid and pressure.
symptoms: Ear pain, which can be constant or intermittent
A feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear
Muffled hearing or temporary hearing loss
Fluid drainage from the ear
Fever and irritability, especially in young children
Dizziness or loss of balance
prevention: Dry ears thoroughly after swimming or bathing
Avoid cleaning ears with sharp objects like cotton swabs, which can push wax deeper or injure the ear canal
Prevent common colds and other respiratory infections
Avoid exposure to cigarette smoke
treatment: Apply a warm compress to the affected ear
Take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or paracetamol
A doctor may prescribe antibiotic ear drops for an outer ear infection or oral antibiotics for a middle ear infection
Resting in an upright position rather than lying down can help reduce pressure
Consult a doctor for diagnosis, especially for children

name: Dandruff
description: Dandruff is a common scalp condition that causes flakes of skin to appear. It is not contagious or serious, but it can be embarrassing and sometimes itchy. Mild dandruff can be caused by a dry scalp or sensitivity to hair products. The most common cause of more severe dandruff is seborrheic dermatitis, a condition that turns the skin oily, red, and scaly. A yeast-like fungus called malassezia, which lives on the scalps of most adults, can also contribute to dandruff by irritating the scalp.
symptoms: White or yellowish flakes of dead skin on your hair and shoulders
An itchy, scaly scalp
Red or inflamed skin on the scalp
Symptoms may worsen during the fall and winter when indoor heating can contribute to dry skin.
prevention: Practice good scalp hygiene by shampooing regularly to control oiliness
Manage stress, as it can trigger or worsen dandruff
Eat a healthy diet rich in zinc and B vitamins
Avoid harsh hair styling products that can irritate the scalp
treatment: Use an over-the-counter anti-dandruff shampoo containing ingredients like ketoconazole, selenium sulfide, zinc pyrithione, or coal tar.
Alternate between different types of anti-dandruff shampoos if one stops being effective.
Massage the shampoo into the scalp and leave it on for 5-10 minutes before rinsing.
For severe cases, a doctor may prescribe stronger medicated shampoos, lotions, or oral medications.

name: Minor Injury / Cut
description: Minor cuts, scrapes (abrasions), and puncture wounds are common injuries that break the skin. While they can be painful and may bleed, they usually don't require a trip to the emergency room and can be managed at home. The main goals of first aid are to stop the bleeding and to clean the wound to prevent infection. Proper care can help the wound heal faster and reduce the risk of scarring.
symptoms: A break in the skin
Bleeding, ranging from mild to moderate
Pain and redness around the wound
Possible swelling
prevention: Be cautious when handling sharp objects like knives or scissors
Keep living and working spaces free of clutter to prevent falls
Wear appropriate protective gear during sports or certain work activities
treatment: Stop the bleeding by applying gentle, direct pressure with a clean cloth or bandage.
Clean the wound by rinsing it with clean water. Use soap on the surrounding skin but try to keep it out of the wound.
Apply a thin layer of an antibiotic ointment to help keep the surface moist and prevent infection.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage to keep it clean.
Seek medical attention if the cut is deep, won't stop bleeding, was caused by a dirty object, or shows signs of infection (pus, increased redness, fever).

name: Period Pain (Dysmenorrhea)
description: Period pain, or dysmenorrhea, is the cramping pain a woman can feel in her lower abdomen, which can occur before or during her menstrual periods. The pain is caused by contractions in the uterus as it sheds its lining. For some women, the discomfort is just a mild annoyance. For others, it can be severe enough to interfere with everyday activities. The pain is not a sign of a serious condition in most cases, but severe pain can sometimes be caused by underlying issues like fibroids or endometriosis.
symptoms: Throbbing or cramping pain in the lower abdomen
Pain that can radiate to the lower back and thighs
Dull, constant ache
May be accompanied by headache, nausea, diarrhea, and fatigue
prevention: Regular exercise can help reduce the severity of cramps
Maintain a healthy diet and reduce salt, sugar, and caffeine intake before your period
Manage stress, as it can worsen pain
Getting enough sleep
treatment: Take over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or mefenamic acid, preferably starting a day before your period is expected.
Apply a heating pad or hot water bottle to your lower abdomen.
Taking a warm bath can help relax muscles.
Gentle exercise like walking or yoga may provide relief.
Hormonal birth control methods often reduce period pain.
Consult a gynecologist if the pain is severe or doesn't improve with self-care.

name: Achalasia
description: Achalasia is a rare, serious primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) muscle to relax during swallowing and a lack of normal peristalsis (muscle contractions) in the esophagus. This makes it difficult for food and liquids to pass into the stomach. The underlying cause is believed to be the degeneration of nerve cells in the esophagus, although the reason for this degeneration is often unknown. Food can get stuck, causing significant discomfort, regurgitation, chest pain, and potential complications like aspiration pneumonia.
symptoms: Difficulty swallowing solids and liquids (dysphagia)
Regurgitation of undigested food
Sharp chest pain, especially after eating
Unintentional weight loss
Heartburn that doesn't respond to antacids
Coughing, especially at night
Feeling of a lump in the throat
prevention: As the cause is often unknown, direct prevention is not possible.
Early medical consultation for persistent swallowing issues is crucial.
Eating slowly and chewing food thoroughly.
Drinking plenty of water with meals to help food pass.
Avoiding late-night meals or lying down immediately after eating.
treatment: Pneumatic (balloon) dilation to stretch the LES
Heller myotomy (surgery to cut the LES muscle)
Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM), a less invasive surgical approach
Botulinum toxin (Botox) injections into the LES
Muscle-relaxing medications like nitrates or calcium channel blockers

name: Acid Reflux (GERD)
description: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), commonly known as acid reflux, is a chronic condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the esophagus. This backwash (reflux) occurs when the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), a muscular ring at the bottom of the esophagus, weakens or relaxes inappropriately. Triggers include certain foods (spicy, fatty, acidic), overeating, obesity, smoking, and pregnancy. If left untreated, frequent acid reflux can lead to complications like esophagitis, esophageal strictures, and an increased risk of esophageal cancer (Barrett's esophagus).
symptoms: A burning sensation in the chest (heartburn), often after eating or at night
Chest pain
Regurgitation of food or sour liquid
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
Chronic cough or laryngitis
Sensation of a lump in the throat
New or worsening asthma
prevention: Eat smaller, more frequent meals instead of large ones
Avoid trigger foods like spicy foods, caffeine, alcohol, chocolate, and fatty foods
Maintain a healthy weight to reduce pressure on the abdomen
Avoid lying down for at least 3 hours after a meal
Elevate the head of your bed by 6-8 inches
Quit smoking
treatment: Over-the-counter antacids for immediate relief
H2 receptor blockers (e.g., famotidine)
Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) to reduce acid production (e.g., omeprazole)
Significant lifestyle and dietary changes
In severe cases, anti-reflux surgery (fundoplication)

name: Acne Vulgaris
description: Acne vulgaris is a very common chronic skin condition resulting from clogged hair follicles. It involves four main factors: excess sebum (oil) production, a buildup of dead skin cells that plug pores, colonization by the bacteria *Propionibacterium acnes*, and subsequent inflammation. It typically appears on the face, forehead, chest, upper back, and shoulders where oil glands are most numerous. While most common among teenagers due to hormonal changes (androgens), it can affect people of all ages.
symptoms: Whiteheads (closed plugged pores)
Blackheads (open plugged pores)
Papules (small red, tender bumps)
Pimples/Pustules (papules with pus at their tips)
Nodules (large, solid, painful lumps beneath the skin)
Cystic lesions (painful, pus-filled lumps beneath the skin)
Oily skin and scarring
prevention: Wash your face twice daily with a gentle, non-abrasive cleanser
Use non-comedogenic (won't clog pores) skincare and makeup products
Avoid touching your face frequently to prevent transferring bacteria
Shampoo hair regularly to keep oil away from the face
Maintain a balanced diet and manage stress
treatment: Topical treatments (benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, retinoids, topical antibiotics)
Oral medications (antibiotics, oral contraceptives for hormonal acne, isotretinoin for severe cases)
Light therapy or chemical peels
Drainage and extraction of large cysts by a dermatologist

name: Allergic Rhinitis
description: Allergic rhinitis, or hay fever, is an immune system response to airborne allergens. When a person with this condition inhales an allergen like pollen, dust mites, mold, or pet dander, their body releases chemicals like histamine, which cause inflammation and cold-like symptoms. It can be seasonal (occurring during specific pollen seasons) or perennial (year-round). It is a widespread condition, particularly in urban areas with high levels of pollution, which can exacerbate symptoms.
symptoms: Frequent sneezing
Runny or stuffy nose (rhinorrhea and congestion)
Itchy, red, or watery eyes (allergic conjunctivitis)
Itchy nose, throat, or roof of the mouth
Postnasal drip
Fatigue and dark circles under the eyes (allergic shiners)
prevention: Identify and avoid known allergens
Use HEPA air purifiers in the home
Keep windows and doors closed during high pollen seasons
Wash bedding in hot water weekly to kill dust mites
Shower after being outdoors to remove pollen from skin and hair
Regularly clean and vacuum to reduce dust and dander
treatment: Oral antihistamines (e.g., loratadine, cetirizine)
Nasal corticosteroid sprays to reduce inflammation
Decongestants for short-term relief of stuffiness
Leukotriene modifiers
Allergy shots (allergen immunotherapy) for long-term management

name: Alzheimer’s Disease
description: Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive, irreversible neurodegenerative disorder and the most common cause of dementia. It is characterized by the formation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles in the brain, which lead to the death of brain cells and subsequent cognitive decline. The disease slowly destroys memory, thinking skills, and eventually, the ability to perform simple daily tasks. In India, its prevalence is rising with increasing life expectancy. While there is no cure, early diagnosis and management can temporarily slow the worsening of symptoms and improve quality of life.
symptoms: Memory loss that disrupts daily life
Confusion with time or place
Difficulty with problem-solving or planning
Trouble speaking or writing
Misplacing things and being unable to retrace steps
Withdrawal from social activities
Changes in mood, personality, and behavior
prevention: Engage in regular mental exercises like puzzles or learning new skills
Maintain a heart-healthy diet (e.g., Mediterranean diet)
Stay socially and physically active
Manage cardiovascular risk factors like high blood pressure, diabetes, and high cholesterol
Get adequate quality sleep
treatment: Cognitive and behavioral therapies
Medications like cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) and memantine
Creating a safe, supportive, and routine-oriented environment
Supportive care for both the patient and caregivers
Managing co-existing conditions

name: Anemia
description: Anemia is a condition in which the blood lacks a sufficient number of healthy red blood cells or hemoglobin to carry adequate oxygen to the body's tissues. The most common type globally and in India is iron-deficiency anemia, especially prevalent among women and children due to inadequate nutrition, parasitic infections, and blood loss. Other causes include deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, chronic diseases, and genetic conditions. Symptoms result from oxygen deprivation and can range from mild fatigue to severe complications, particularly during pregnancy.
symptoms: Persistent fatigue and weakness
Pale skin, lips, and nail beds
Shortness of breath, especially with exertion
Dizziness or lightheadedness
Cold hands and feet
Headaches
Brittle nails or a sore tongue
prevention: Eat a balanced diet rich in iron (leafy greens, red meat, legumes), vitamin B12, and folic acid
Consume vitamin C-rich foods (citrus fruits, bell peppers) to enhance iron absorption
Take prescribed supplements, especially during pregnancy
Regular health checkups to screen for anemia
Promptly treat underlying conditions that cause blood loss or malabsorption
treatment: Iron supplements (oral or intravenous)
Vitamin B12 or folic acid supplements/injections
Dietary modifications to include nutrient-rich foods
Blood transfusions in cases of severe anemia
Medications to stimulate red blood cell production

name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
description: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease and a type of arthritis that primarily affects the spine's joints (vertebrae) and the sacroiliac joints in the pelvis. The inflammation can lead to severe, chronic pain, stiffness, and in advanced cases, new bone formation can cause parts of the spine to fuse in a fixed, immobile position, often resulting in a hunched-forward posture. The condition has a strong genetic link (HLA-B27 gene) and typically begins in early adulthood. Early diagnosis and consistent treatment are key to managing pain and maintaining flexibility.
symptoms: Chronic pain and stiffness in the lower back and hips, especially in the morning or after inactivity
Reduced flexibility of the spine
Persistent fatigue
Pain in other joints like the ribs, shoulders, and heels
Inflammation of the eyes (uveitis)
prevention: AS cannot be prevented, but its progression can be managed.
Regular exercise and physical therapy to maintain flexibility and posture
Practicing good posture throughout the day
Avoiding smoking, as it can worsen the condition
treatment: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
Physiotherapy and specific stretching exercises
Biologic medications like TNF blockers and IL-17 inhibitors
Pain management strategies
In rare, severe cases, surgery may be considered

name: Anorexia Nervosa
description: Anorexia nervosa is a severe and potentially life-threatening eating disorder characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight, a distorted body image, and self-imposed starvation leading to significantly low body weight. Individuals with anorexia place a high value on controlling their weight and shape, using extreme efforts that interfere with their lives. The disorder often begins during adolescence. The physical consequences of starvation can be severe, affecting major organs like the heart and brain, and leading to bone loss and infertility. Recovery requires a comprehensive treatment approach.
symptoms: Extreme weight loss or being significantly underweight
Intense fear of gaining weight
Distorted body image (seeing oneself as overweight despite being thin)
Refusal to eat or severe restriction of food intake
Fatigue, dizziness, or fainting
Absence of menstruation (amenorrhea) in females
Social withdrawal and obsession with food/calories
prevention: Promoting a healthy body image and self-esteem not tied to appearance
Discouraging dieting and weight-focused talk
Early counseling for individuals showing signs of body dissatisfaction or disordered eating
Creating a supportive family environment that encourages open communication
treatment: Multidisciplinary care involving psychological therapy (e.g., CBT, Family-Based Treatment)
Medical monitoring to stabilize physical health
Nutritional counseling and support to restore a healthy weight
Hospitalization or residential treatment in severe cases
Medications for co-occurring conditions like depression or anxiety

name: Anthrax
description: Anthrax is a rare but serious infectious disease caused by the spore-forming bacterium *Bacillus anthracis*. It primarily affects livestock and wild animals, but humans can become infected through contact with infected animals or contaminated animal products. The infection can occur in three main forms: cutaneous (skin), inhalation (lungs), and gastrointestinal (ingestion), depending on the route of exposure. Inhalation anthrax is the most deadly. Prompt treatment with antibiotics is crucial for survival.
symptoms: Cutaneous: A group of small, itchy blisters that develop into a painless skin sore with a black center.
Inhalation: Flu-like symptoms (fever, cough, chest pain) that rapidly progress to severe breathing difficulty and shock.
Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fever, and bloody diarrhea.
prevention: Vaccination for livestock in endemic areas
Vaccination for high-risk individuals (e.g., lab workers, veterinarians)
Using protective equipment when handling potentially infected animals or their products
Avoiding consumption of meat from animals that died of unknown causes
treatment: A long course (60 days) of antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin or doxycycline
Antitoxin therapy to neutralize the toxins produced by the bacteria
Hospitalization and intensive supportive care for severe cases

name: Anxiety Disorders
description: Anxiety disorders are a category of mental health conditions characterized by intense, excessive, and persistent worry and fear about everyday situations. These feelings are out of proportion to the actual danger and can interfere with daily activities. Types include Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), Panic Disorder, Social Anxiety Disorder, and specific phobias. Often, they involve repeated episodes of sudden, intense anxiety and fear or terror that reach a peak within minutes (panic attacks).
symptoms: Feeling nervous, restless, or tense (excessive worrying)
A sense of impending danger, panic, or doom
Increased heart rate and rapid breathing (hyperventilation)
Sweating, trembling, and fatigue
Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
Trouble sleeping
Avoidance of situations that trigger anxiety
prevention: Learn and practice stress management and relaxation techniques (e.g., meditation, yoga)
Seek therapy or counseling at the first signs of distress
Limit caffeine and alcohol, which can worsen anxiety
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise, a balanced diet, and sufficient sleep
Build a strong social support network
treatment: Psychotherapy, particularly Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and exposure therapy
Medications like antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs)
Anti-anxiety medications (benzodiazepines) for short-term use
Lifestyle modifications including exercise and mindfulness practices

name: Aplastic Anemia
description: Aplastic anemia is a rare but very serious blood disorder where the bone marrow fails to produce enough new blood cells (red cells, white cells, and platelets). This condition, known as bone marrow failure, leads to a shortage of all three blood cell types (pancytopenia). It can be acquired, possibly triggered by toxins, radiation, or an autoimmune response where the body's immune system attacks its own stem cells, or it can be inherited. The condition can develop suddenly or slowly and can be life-threatening without prompt and appropriate treatment.
symptoms: Fatigue and shortness of breath (due to low red blood cells)
Frequent or prolonged infections (due to low white blood cells)
Easy bruising or bleeding, including nosebleeds and bleeding gums (due to low platelets)
Dizziness and headaches
Pale skin and rapid heart rate
prevention: True prevention is often not possible as the cause is frequently unknown.
Avoid exposure to toxic chemicals like benzene, insecticides, and herbicides.
Protect against infections, which can be severe in individuals with this condition.
treatment: Blood transfusions to manage symptoms
Immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., anti-thymocyte globulin and cyclosporine) to stop the immune attack
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant, which can be a cure
Medications to stimulate the bone marrow

name: Appendicitis
description: Appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix, a small, finger-shaped pouch that projects from the large intestine on the lower right side of the abdomen. The inflammation is typically caused by a blockage in the lining of the appendix, which leads to infection and swelling. The condition causes sudden and severe pain. Appendicitis is considered a medical emergency because if the inflamed appendix is not removed, it can rupture, spreading infection throughout the abdomen (peritonitis), which can be fatal.
symptoms: Sudden pain that begins around the navel and often shifts to the lower right abdomen
Pain that worsens with coughing, walking, or other jarring movements
Nausea and vomiting
Loss of appetite
Low-grade fever that may worsen as the illness progresses
Abdominal bloating, constipation, or diarrhea
prevention: There is no guaranteed way to prevent appendicitis.
Some evidence suggests that a high-fiber diet, rich in fruits and vegetables, may be associated with a lower risk, though this is not definitive.
treatment: Surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy), which can be done via open surgery or laparoscopically
Antibiotics are administered before and after surgery to prevent infection
In some uncomplicated cases, antibiotic therapy alone may be considered, but surgery remains the standard treatment.

name: Arthritis
description: Arthritis is a general term for conditions that cause inflammation in the joints, leading to pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced mobility. The two most common types are Osteoarthritis (OA) and Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). Osteoarthritis is a degenerative 'wear-and-tear' condition where joint cartilage breaks down over time. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the lining of the joints. In India, arthritis is a major cause of disability, significantly affecting daily activities and overall quality of life.
symptoms: Persistent joint pain and tenderness
Stiffness, especially in the morning or after periods of inactivity
Swelling, warmth, or redness in a joint
Difficulty moving a joint or decreased range of motion
A grating sensation during joint movement
prevention: Engage in regular, low-impact exercise (e.g., swimming, cycling) to strengthen muscles around joints
Maintain a healthy weight to reduce stress on weight-bearing joints like knees and hips
Protect joints from injury by using proper form during activities
Eat an anti-inflammatory diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids
treatment: Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
Physical therapy to improve range of motion and strengthen muscles
Corticosteroid injections to reduce inflammation
Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and biologics for RA
Joint replacement surgery for severely damaged joints

name: Asthma
description: Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways (bronchial tubes). This inflammation makes the airways sensitive to various triggers, such as allergens, smoke, cold air, or exercise. When exposed to a trigger, the airways can swell, the muscles around them tighten, and excess mucus is produced. This leads to symptoms like coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness, which can range from mild to life-threatening.
symptoms: Shortness of breath
Chest tightness or pain
A whistling or wheezing sound when exhaling
Coughing, especially at night, during exercise, or when laughing
Trouble sleeping due to respiratory symptoms
prevention: Identify and avoid personal asthma triggers (e.g., pollen, dust mites, smoke)
Use preventive (long-term control) inhalers as prescribed by a doctor
Monitor breathing with a peak flow meter
Get annual flu and pneumonia vaccinations
Develop and follow an asthma action plan with your doctor
treatment: Quick-relief (rescue) inhalers like albuterol for immediate symptom relief
Long-term control medications, such as inhaled corticosteroids, to reduce inflammation
Bronchodilators to open the airways
Leukotriene modifiers
Lifestyle management and trigger avoidance

name: Bacterial Vaginosis
description: Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common vaginal condition resulting from an imbalance in the natural vaginal flora. It involves an overgrowth of certain anaerobic bacteria and a decrease in the beneficial lactobacilli that normally maintain an acidic environment. While not considered a sexually transmitted infection (STI), risk factors include new or multiple sexual partners and douching, which disrupts the natural balance. BV can increase the risk of contracting STIs and may cause complications in pregnancy.
symptoms: A thin, gray, white, or green vaginal discharge
A foul-smelling 'fishy' vaginal odor, which may be more pronounced after intercourse
Vaginal itching or irritation
A burning sensation during urination
Note: Many women with BV experience no symptoms at all.
prevention: Avoid douching, as it upsets the natural vaginal balance
Use mild, non-irritating soaps and avoid scented feminine hygiene products
Wear breathable cotton underwear
Practice safe sex and limit the number of sexual partners
treatment: Antibiotics, most commonly metronidazole or clindamycin, which can be taken orally or applied as a vaginal cream/gel
Completing the full course of medication is important to prevent recurrence
Probiotics may help restore the balance of healthy bacteria

name: Bedsores
description: Bedsores, also known as pressure ulcers or decubitus ulcers, are injuries to the skin and underlying tissue resulting from prolonged pressure. This pressure reduces blood flow, leading to tissue damage and death. They commonly develop on skin that covers bony areas of the body, such as the heels, ankles, hips, and tailbone. Individuals who are bedridden, use a wheelchair, or are unable to change positions on their own are at highest risk. Bedsores can range from mild redness to deep wounds extending to muscle and bone, posing a serious risk of infection if not properly managed.
symptoms: Unusual changes in skin color or texture
Swelling and pus-like draining
An area of skin that feels cooler or warmer to the touch than other areas
Pain or tenderness in the affected area
Skin breakdown, ranging from a shallow open sore to a deep crater
prevention: Frequent repositioning (at least every two hours in bed, every hour in a chair)
Use of special cushions, pads, or pressure-reducing mattresses
Keeping the skin clean, dry, and well-moisturized
Ensuring good nutrition and hydration to promote healthy skin
treatment: Relieving pressure on the affected area
Regularly cleaning the wound and applying special medicated dressings
Debridement (removal of dead or infected tissue)
Negative pressure wound therapy
In severe, non-healing cases, surgery may be required

name: Bell’s Palsy
description: Bell's palsy is a condition that causes a sudden, temporary weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. This occurs when the seventh cranial nerve, which controls facial muscles, becomes inflamed, swollen, or compressed. The exact cause is unknown, but it is strongly linked to viral infections, such as the herpes simplex virus. The onset is rapid, often developing overnight. While the symptoms can be alarming, most individuals achieve a full or near-full recovery within a few weeks to six months, especially with prompt treatment.
symptoms: Rapid onset of mild to total paralysis on one side of the face
Facial drooping and difficulty making facial expressions, like closing an eye or smiling
Drooling from one side of the mouth
Loss of taste on the front of the tongue
Increased sensitivity to sound in the affected ear (hyperacusis)
Pain around the jaw or behind the ear
prevention: There is no known way to prevent Bell's palsy.
Maintaining good overall health and immunity may reduce the risk of viral infections that can trigger it.
Protecting the face from cold winds is a traditional but unproven recommendation.
treatment: Corticosteroid medications (like prednisone) to reduce inflammation, most effective if started within 72 hours
Antiviral drugs may be prescribed alongside steroids
Physical therapy and facial exercises to stimulate muscles
Protective eye care (eye drops, ointments, eye patch) to prevent the cornea from drying out

name: Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH)
description: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a common, non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland that occurs as men age. The prostate gland surrounds the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder out of the body. As the prostate enlarges, it can squeeze or partially block the urethra, leading to a variety of uncomfortable and disruptive urinary symptoms. BPH does not increase the risk of prostate cancer, but the symptoms can significantly impact quality of life.
symptoms: Frequent or urgent need to urinate, especially at night (nocturia)
Difficulty starting urination (hesitancy)
A weak or interrupted urine stream
Dribbling at the end of urination
Inability to completely empty the bladder
Straining while urinating
prevention: BPH is considered a normal part of aging and is not preventable.
Lifestyle factors, such as maintaining a healthy weight, regular exercise, and a diet rich in fruits and vegetables, may help manage symptoms and overall prostate health.
treatment: Watchful waiting for mild symptoms
Medications like alpha-blockers to relax bladder neck muscles and 5-alpha reductase inhibitors to shrink the prostate
Minimally invasive procedures (e.g., laser therapy, UroLift)
Surgery, such as transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP), to remove excess prostate tissue

name: Beriberi
description: Beriberi is a disease caused by a severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Thiamine is crucial for breaking down sugars and for the proper functioning of the nervous system and heart. The disease is categorized into two main types: wet beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular system, and dry beriberi, which damages the nerves and can lead to muscle paralysis. It is most common in populations with poor nutrition, diets high in polished white rice, and in individuals with chronic alcoholism. If left untreated, it can be fatal.
symptoms: Dry Beriberi: Numbness and tingling in hands and feet, muscle weakness or wasting, difficulty walking, confusion.
Wet Beriberi: Shortness of breath with activity or when lying down, rapid heart rate, swelling in the lower legs (edema).
General symptoms: Weakness, pain in the limbs, loss of appetite.
prevention: Eat a balanced diet rich in thiamine-containing foods like whole grains, legumes, pork, nuts, and seeds
Avoid excessive alcohol consumption, as it impairs thiamine absorption
Choose brown rice or fortified white rice over polished white rice
treatment: Immediate administration of high-dose thiamine supplements, often initially via injection followed by oral tablets
A nutritious, balanced diet to correct nutritional deficiencies
Medical monitoring to manage cardiovascular or neurological symptoms
Addressing underlying causes like alcoholism

name: Bipolar Disorder
description: Bipolar disorder is a serious mental health condition characterized by extreme and intense shifts in mood, energy levels, thinking patterns, and behavior. These shifts, known as mood episodes, range from emotional highs (manic or hypomanic episodes) to severe lows (depressive episodes). The condition is lifelong and requires long-term management. There are different types, with Bipolar I involving at least one manic episode and Bipolar II involving hypomanic and depressive episodes. These dramatic mood swings can disrupt work, school, relationships, and daily functioning.
symptoms: Manic/Hypomanic Episodes: Abnormally high energy, euphoria, inflated self-esteem, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, impulsivity, and risky behavior.
Depressive Episodes: Profound sadness, hopelessness, loss of interest in activities, significant changes in sleep or appetite, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness, and thoughts of suicide.
prevention: While the disorder itself cannot be prevented, proactive management can help prevent mood episodes.
Adherence to a consistent treatment plan
Establishing a regular routine for sleep, diet, and exercise
Avoiding alcohol and recreational drugs
Early recognition of warning signs of a mood shift
treatment: Mood-stabilizing medications (e.g., lithium, valproic acid)
Antipsychotic medications
Antidepressants (used cautiously with a mood stabilizer)
Psychotherapy (e.g., CBT, psychoeducation) for the individual and family
Lifestyle management, including stress reduction and maintaining a stable routine

name: Blastomycosis
description: Blastomycosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by inhaling the spores of the fungus *Blastomyces dermatitidis*. This fungus is typically found in moist soil and decaying organic matter, such as wood and leaves, in certain regions. The infection usually starts in the lungs and can cause pneumonia-like symptoms. In some cases, especially in individuals with weakened immune systems, the infection can disseminate (spread) from the lungs to other parts of the body, most commonly the skin, bones, and central nervous system.
symptoms: Pulmonary (Lung) Infection: Fever, cough, chest pain, night sweats, muscle aches, and fatigue.
Disseminated (Widespread) Infection: Skin lesions that may appear as warts, blisters, or ulcers; bone pain and swelling; neurological symptoms like headache or seizures if the brain is involved.
prevention: It is difficult to avoid exposure in areas where the fungus is common.
Individuals with compromised immune systems should be cautious when participating in activities that disturb soil, like digging or construction, in endemic areas.
Wearing a protective N95 mask may reduce the risk of inhaling spores.
treatment: Antifungal medications are required for treatment.
Itraconazole is typically used for mild to moderate cases, often for 6 to 12 months.
Amphotericin B is used for severe or life-threatening infections, especially those involving the central nervous system.

name: Bronchiectasis
description: Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition where the airways (bronchi) become permanently damaged, widened, and thickened. This damage impairs the cilia, the tiny hair-like structures that help clear mucus from the lungs. As a result, mucus builds up, creating an environment where bacteria can thrive, leading to frequent and severe respiratory infections. The condition can be caused by underlying issues like cystic fibrosis, severe pneumonia, or autoimmune diseases, and it leads to a cycle of inflammation and infection that further damages the airways.
symptoms: A persistent daily cough that produces large amounts of thick mucus (sputum)
Recurrent chest infections (bronchitis or pneumonia)
Shortness of breath and wheezing
Coughing up blood or blood-streaked mucus (hemoptysis)
Fatigue and general feeling of being unwell
Clubbing of the fingertips in advanced cases
prevention: Prompt and effective treatment of lung infections, especially in childhood
Receiving recommended vaccinations (influenza, pneumococcal)
Avoiding smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke
Managing underlying conditions that can lead to bronchiectasis, such as GERD or autoimmune diseases.
treatment: Antibiotics to treat and prevent infections (oral, inhaled, or IV)
Airway clearance techniques (e.g., chest physiotherapy, oscillating vests)
Mucus-thinning medications (mucolytics)
Bronchodilators to open airways
In rare cases, surgery to remove the affected section of the lung

name: Bronchitis
description: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the lining of the bronchial tubes, which are the main air passages to the lungs. It is categorized as either acute or chronic. Acute bronchitis is very common, often developing after a viral infection like a cold, and usually resolves within a few weeks. Chronic bronchitis is a more serious condition, defined as a productive cough lasting at least three months a year for two consecutive years. It is a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is most often caused by long-term exposure to irritants like cigarette smoke and pollution.
symptoms: Persistent cough, which may produce clear, white, yellow, or greenish mucus
Chest discomfort or soreness
Wheezing and shortness of breath
Fatigue
Slight fever and chills (more common in acute bronchitis)
prevention: Avoid smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke, the primary cause of chronic bronchitis
Reduce exposure to air pollution and other lung irritants
Practice good hand hygiene to prevent viral infections
Get an annual flu shot
treatment: For Acute Bronchitis: Rest, fluids, and a humidifier. Cough suppressants may be used. Antibiotics are generally not effective as the cause is usually viral.
For Chronic Bronchitis: Bronchodilators, inhaled steroids, pulmonary rehabilitation, and oxygen therapy.

name: Brucellosis
description: Brucellosis is a bacterial infectious disease that spreads from animals to people (a zoonotic disease). It is most often transmitted by consuming unpasteurized or raw dairy products from infected animals like goats, cows, or sheep. It can also be transmitted through inhaling the bacteria or through contact with infected animal fluids via skin cuts. It is an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and slaughterhouse workers. The infection can cause long-lasting flu-like symptoms and may become chronic if not treated properly.
symptoms: Fever that comes and goes (undulant fever)
Profuse sweating, especially at night
Weakness, fatigue, and body aches
Joint and muscle pain, particularly back pain
Headaches
Loss of appetite and weight loss
prevention: Avoid consuming unpasteurized dairy products (milk, cheese, ice cream).
Wear protective clothing, gloves, and glasses when handling animals or their tissues.
Vaccinate domestic livestock.
Thoroughly cook all meat.
treatment: A combination of antibiotics, such as doxycycline and rifampin, is required for at least six weeks to prevent relapse.
Long-term medical follow-up is necessary as symptoms can persist or recur.

name: Bulimia Nervosa
description: Bulimia nervosa is a serious, potentially life-threatening eating disorder characterized by a repeating cycle of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors. A binge involves eating an unusually large amount of food in a discrete period with a sense of lack of control. This is followed by purging behaviors, such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives or diuretics, fasting, or excessive exercise, to prevent weight gain. The disorder is often driven by an intense preoccupation with body weight and shape. The cycle can cause severe physical complications, including electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, and damage to the digestive system.
symptoms: Recurrent episodes of binge eating and purging
Preoccupation with body weight and shape
Living in fear of gaining weight
Sore throat, swollen salivary glands (puffy cheeks)
Tooth decay and erosion from stomach acid
Gastrointestinal problems like acid reflux
Feeling out of control during a binge
prevention: Promote a positive body image and self-esteem
Encourage healthy, balanced eating habits rather than restrictive dieting
Develop healthy coping strategies for stress and emotional distress
Early intervention and counseling for individuals showing signs of the disorder
treatment: Psychotherapy, particularly Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT), is the cornerstone of treatment
Nutritional counseling to help normalize eating patterns
Antidepressant medications, such as fluoxetine (Prozac)
A multidisciplinary team approach involving doctors, mental health professionals, and dietitians

name: Cancer (Breast and Cervical)
description: Breast and cervical cancers are two of the most common cancers affecting women in India. Breast cancer originates in the cells of the breast, often in the ducts or lobules. Cervical cancer develops in the cervix and is almost always caused by persistent infection with high-risk strains of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV). For both cancers, early detection through regular screening and awareness of symptoms is critical for improving treatment success rates and survival.
symptoms: Breast Cancer: A new lump in the breast or underarm, changes in breast size or shape, nipple discharge, skin changes (dimpling, redness).
Cervical Cancer (often asymptomatic early): Unusual vaginal bleeding (after intercourse, between periods), watery or foul-smelling discharge, pelvic pain.
General: Persistent cough, unexplained weight loss, or changes in bowel habits can be signs of advanced cancer.
prevention: Regular screenings: Mammograms for breast cancer and Pap/HPV tests for cervical cancer.
HPV vaccination is highly effective in preventing cervical cancer.
Healthy lifestyle: Maintain a healthy weight, be physically active, limit alcohol, and do not smoke.
Breast self-awareness and prompt medical consultation for any changes.
treatment: Surgery (e.g., lumpectomy, mastectomy, hysterectomy)
Radiation therapy to kill cancer cells
Chemotherapy (systemic drugs to destroy cancer cells)
Hormone therapy (for hormone-sensitive breast cancers)
Targeted therapy and immunotherapy

name: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
description: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a common condition that causes pain, numbness, and tingling in the hand and arm. It occurs when the median nerve, one of the major nerves to the hand, is squeezed or compressed as it travels through the wrist. The carpal tunnel is a narrow passageway on the palm side of the wrist, and any swelling from inflammation can compress the nerve. Factors that can contribute to the condition include wrist anatomy, repetitive hand motions, pregnancy, and underlying health problems like diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis.
symptoms: Numbness, tingling, or burning sensation, primarily in the thumb, index, middle, and ring fingers
Weakness in the hand and a tendency to drop objects
Pain that may radiate from the wrist up the arm
Symptoms that are often worse at night and may awaken the person from sleep
Shock-like sensations in the fingers
prevention: Take frequent breaks from repetitive hand and wrist tasks
Improve posture and ensure ergonomic setup at workstations
Perform regular wrist and hand stretching exercises
Keep hands and wrists warm to keep muscles flexible
Avoid flexing and extending the wrist for prolonged periods
treatment: Wearing a wrist splint, especially at night, to keep the wrist in a neutral position
Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
Corticosteroid injections into the carpal tunnel to reduce inflammation
Physical therapy and yoga
In persistent or severe cases, carpal tunnel release surgery to relieve pressure on the nerve

name: Cataract
description: A cataract is a clouding of the eye's natural lens, which lies behind the iris and the pupil. The lens works much like a camera lens, focusing light onto the retina for clear vision. As a cataract develops, the lens becomes opaque, preventing light from passing through easily and causing vision to become blurry or dim. It is a very common condition, primarily related to aging, but can also be caused by eye injuries, diabetes, prolonged steroid use, or excessive sun exposure. Surgery is a highly effective and common procedure to restore clear vision.
symptoms: Cloudy, blurry, or dim vision
Increasing difficulty with vision at night
Sensitivity to light and glare
Seeing 'halos' around lights
Fading or yellowing of colors
Frequent changes in eyeglass or contact lens prescription
prevention: Protect eyes from ultraviolet (UV) radiation by wearing sunglasses
Manage health problems like diabetes effectively
Quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption
Eat a diet rich in antioxidants (fruits and vegetables)
Undergo regular comprehensive eye examinations
treatment: In early stages, stronger eyeglasses and brighter lighting can help.
The only effective treatment for advanced cataracts is surgery.
Cataract surgery involves removing the clouded lens and replacing it with a clear, artificial intraocular lens (IOL).

name: Celiac Disease
description: Celiac disease is a chronic, immune-mediated disorder triggered by the consumption of gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. In individuals with this condition, eating gluten causes the immune system to attack and damage the villi, the tiny, finger-like projections lining the small intestine. This damage impairs the body's ability to absorb nutrients from food, leading to malabsorption and a wide range of digestive and non-digestive symptoms. A strict, lifelong gluten-free diet is the only treatment to manage the disease and allow the intestine to heal.
symptoms: Digestive issues like chronic diarrhea, bloating, gas, and abdominal pain
Unexplained weight loss
Persistent fatigue and weakness
Iron-deficiency anemia that doesn't respond to iron supplements
An itchy, blistering skin rash (dermatitis herpetiformis)
Mouth ulcers, headaches, and joint pain
prevention: The disease itself cannot be prevented, but its symptoms and complications can be prevented by strict dietary adherence.
Completely avoid all foods and products containing wheat, barley, rye, and their derivatives.
Read food labels carefully to check for hidden gluten.
Prevent cross-contamination in the kitchen.
treatment: A strict, lifelong gluten-free diet is the only effective treatment.
Consultation with a dietitian specializing in celiac disease.
Vitamin and mineral supplements to correct nutritional deficiencies (e.g., iron, calcium, vitamin D, B12).
Regular medical follow-up to monitor intestinal healing and overall health.

name: Cervical Cancer
description: Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that occurs in the cells of the cervix, the lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina. It is caused almost exclusively by persistent infection with high-risk strains of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV), a common sexually transmitted infection. The progression from HPV infection to cancer is typically very slow, often taking years. This slow development allows for early detection of precancerous cellular changes through regular screening, making it a highly preventable and treatable cancer when caught early.
symptoms: Early-stage cervical cancer is often asymptomatic.
Abnormal vaginal bleeding, such as after intercourse, between periods, or after menopause.
Watery, bloody vaginal discharge that may be heavy and have a foul odor.
Pelvic pain or pain during intercourse.
prevention: HPV vaccination, which is highly effective against the main cancer-causing HPV types.
Regular screening with Pap tests and/or HPV tests to detect precancerous cells.
Practicing safe sex, including consistent condom use, to reduce the risk of HPV transmission.
Not smoking, as smoking increases the risk.
treatment: For precancerous cells: Procedures like cone biopsy or LEEP.
For early-stage cancer: Surgery (e.g., hysterectomy) or radiation therapy.
For advanced cancer: A combination of radiation therapy and chemotherapy (chemoradiation).
Targeted therapy and immunotherapy may be used in some cases.

name: Cervical Spondylosis
description: Cervical spondylosis is a general term for age-related degenerative 'wear and tear' affecting the spinal disks and joints in the neck. As people age, the intervertebral disks can dehydrate and shrink, leading to signs of osteoarthritis, such as the development of bony projections (bone spurs). These changes can narrow the space within the spinal canal, potentially compressing the spinal cord or nerve roots. It is an extremely common condition and, while often asymptomatic, can cause chronic neck pain and stiffness.
symptoms: Neck pain and stiffness that may worsen with activity
A grinding or popping sensation when turning the neck
Headaches, often originating from the neck
Pain, numbness, or weakness that radiates into the shoulders, arms, or hands
In severe cases (with spinal cord compression): loss of balance, coordination problems, and loss of bladder or bowel control.
prevention: Maintain good posture, especially when sitting or using screens
Perform regular neck stretching and strengthening exercises
Avoid neck strain and heavy lifting with improper form
Stay physically active to maintain spinal flexibility
Use a supportive pillow for sleeping.
treatment: Over-the-counter pain relievers (NSAIDs)
Physical therapy to improve neck strength and flexibility
Temporarily wearing a soft cervical collar or brace
Steroid injections to reduce inflammation and pain
In severe cases where nerves are compressed, surgery may be necessary

name: Chancroid
description: Chancroid is a bacterial sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by *Haemophilus ducreyi*. It is characterized by the development of one or more painful ulcers on or around the genital area. It can also cause the lymph nodes in the groin to become swollen and painful, forming a pus-filled abscess called a bubo. Chancroid is more common in tropical and subtropical regions with limited healthcare resources. Importantly, the open sores of chancroid can increase the risk of transmitting or acquiring other STIs, including HIV.
symptoms: One or more painful, soft genital ulcers with ragged edges
Ulcers may bleed easily if touched
Swollen, tender, and painful lymph nodes in the groin area
Pain during urination or sexual intercourse
prevention: Consistent and correct use of condoms during sexual activity
Abstaining from sexual contact or being in a mutually monogamous relationship with an uninfected partner
Regular STI screening if sexually active
Maintaining good personal hygiene
treatment: A course of antibiotics, often a single dose of azithromycin or ceftriaxone, is highly effective.
Proper wound care for the ulcers
In some cases, draining of the swollen lymph nodes (buboes) may be necessary to relieve pain.
Sexual partners should also be tested and treated.

name: Chiari Malformation
description: A Chiari malformation is a congenital structural defect in the cerebellum, the part of the brain that controls balance. In this condition, brain tissue at the base of the skull extends into the spinal canal. This can block the normal flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), leading to a buildup of pressure and a range of neurological symptoms. There are several types, with Type I being the most common, often not diagnosed until adolescence or adulthood. The severity of symptoms can vary greatly among individuals.
symptoms: Severe headaches, especially at the back of the head, often triggered by coughing or straining
Neck pain
Dizziness, vertigo, and balance problems (ataxia)
Numbness or tingling in the limbs
Muscle weakness
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
Blurred or double vision
prevention: As Chiari malformations are congenital, they cannot be prevented.
Genetic counseling may be relevant for families with a history of the condition.
Regular monitoring and avoiding activities that strain the neck can help manage symptoms in diagnosed individuals.
treatment: For asymptomatic cases, regular monitoring may be all that is needed.
Pain management with medications
Physical therapy to improve balance and strength
In symptomatic cases, posterior fossa decompression surgery is often performed to create more space for the brain tissue and relieve pressure.

name: Chickenpox
description: Chickenpox is a highly contagious infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It is primarily known for causing an itchy rash with fluid-filled blisters that appear all over the body. While it is most common in children, adults who contract it can experience more severe symptoms. After the initial infection, the virus remains dormant in nerve tissue and can reactivate later in life to cause shingles. Widespread vaccination has made chickenpox much less common, but outbreaks can still occur, particularly in unvaccinated populations.
symptoms: An itchy rash that progresses from red spots (macules) to small fluid-filled blisters (vesicles), which then crust over.
Fever
Fatigue and a general feeling of being unwell (malaise)
Loss of appetite
Headache and sore throat
prevention: The most effective prevention is the varicella (chickenpox) vaccine, typically given in two doses.
Avoiding close contact with infected individuals until all their blisters have scabbed over.
Isolating infected persons to prevent spread to others.
treatment: Symptomatic relief is the main focus of treatment.
Topical lotions (like calamine) or cool oatmeal baths to soothe itching.
Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen for fever (avoid aspirin in children).
Antihistamines to reduce itching.
Antiviral medications like acyclovir may be prescribed for high-risk individuals.

name: Chikungunya
description: Chikungunya is a viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes, primarily the *Aedes aegypti* and *Aedes albopictus* species. The name means 'to become contorted' and describes the stooped appearance of sufferers with severe joint pain. The most prominent symptoms are an abrupt onset of fever and debilitating joint pain. While the disease is rarely fatal, the joint pain can be severe and persistent, lasting for months or even years in some cases. There is no specific antiviral treatment, so care focuses on relieving symptoms.
symptoms: Sudden high fever
Severe and often debilitating pain in multiple joints
Skin rash, typically appearing a few days after the fever
Fatigue and headache
Muscle pain
Nausea and vomiting
prevention: Effective mosquito control measures are crucial.
Use insect repellents containing DEET or picaridin.
Wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants.
Eliminate standing water in and around the home where mosquitoes breed (e.g., in flowerpots, tires, and buckets).
Use window and door screens.
treatment: There is no cure; treatment is supportive.
Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., paracetamol, NSAIDs) to reduce fever and joint pain.
Getting plenty of rest.
Drinking fluids to prevent dehydration.

name: Cholangitis
description: Cholangitis is a serious infection and inflammation of the bile ducts, the tubes that carry bile from the liver and gallbladder to the small intestine. The condition is most often caused by a bacterial infection that occurs when a bile duct becomes blocked, typically by a gallstone. Other causes of blockage can include tumors or strictures. The blockage causes bile to back up, creating a breeding ground for bacteria. Acute cholangitis is a medical emergency that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent life-threatening complications like sepsis.
symptoms: The classic signs are known as Charcot's triad: fever, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), and right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
Chills and rigors
Nausea and vomiting
In severe cases, confusion and low blood pressure (hypotension) may occur.
prevention: Maintain good liver and gallbladder health.
Seek prompt medical treatment for gallstones to prevent them from blocking the bile duct.
Maintain a healthy weight and diet to reduce the risk of forming gallstones.
Regular health checkups if you have a history of biliary disease.
treatment: Hospitalization is required.
Intravenous (IV) antibiotics to fight the infection.
Fluid resuscitation and supportive care.
Urgent biliary drainage to relieve the blockage, usually performed endoscopically (ERCP) or percutaneously (PTC).
Addressing the underlying cause of the blockage once the infection is controlled.

name: Cholera
description: Cholera is an acute, diarrheal illness caused by infection of the intestine with the bacterium *Vibrio cholerae*. People can get sick when they swallow food or water contaminated with the bacteria. The infection is often mild or without symptoms, but about 5-10% of people will have severe disease characterized by profuse watery diarrhea, vomiting, and leg cramps. In these people, rapid loss of body fluids leads to dehydration and shock. Without treatment, death can occur within hours. It is most common in areas with poor sanitation and inadequate access to clean water.
symptoms: Profuse, watery diarrhea, often described as 'rice-water stools'
Vomiting
Rapid dehydration, leading to thirst, dry mouth, and decreased urination
Muscle cramps, especially in the legs
Rapid heart rate and low blood pressure due to fluid loss
prevention: Ensuring access to and use of safe, clean drinking water.
Maintaining proper sanitation and sewage disposal systems.
Practicing good hygiene, especially frequent handwashing with soap and safe water.
Cooking food thoroughly and eating it while it is hot.
Oral cholera vaccines are available for travelers and people in high-risk areas.
treatment: Immediate rehydration is the cornerstone of treatment.
Oral rehydration solutions (ORS), a pre-packaged mixture of sugar and salts, are highly effective.
Intravenous (IV) fluids are required for severely dehydrated patients.
Antibiotics can reduce the duration and severity of the illness in severe cases.
Zinc supplements can help reduce diarrhea in children.

name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
description: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a condition characterized by a gradual and irreversible loss of kidney function over time. The kidneys are responsible for filtering waste products and excess fluids from the blood, which are then excreted in urine. As CKD progresses, the kidneys become less effective at this job, leading to a dangerous buildup of waste, fluids, and electrolytes in the body. The two main causes of CKD are diabetes and high blood pressure. In its final stage, it is known as end-stage renal disease (ESRD), which is fatal without dialysis or a kidney transplant.
symptoms: Symptoms are often subtle or absent in early stages.
As it progresses: fatigue, weakness, swelling in the legs, feet, or ankles (edema).
Reduced urine output or frequent urination, especially at night.
Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite.
Itchy skin, muscle cramps, and difficulty concentrating.
prevention: Strictly manage underlying conditions like diabetes and high blood pressure.
Maintain a healthy diet that is low in salt and processed foods.
Avoid the overuse of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and other medications that can harm the kidneys.
Regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight.
Get regular checkups, including kidney function tests, if you are at high risk.
treatment: Treating the underlying cause (e.g., blood pressure and glucose control).
Medications to manage complications like anemia, high blood pressure, and swelling.
