Dietary restrictions on sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and protein.
For end-stage disease: Dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis) to filter the blood.
Kidney transplant.

name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
description: COPD is a progressive chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, making breathing increasingly difficult. It encompasses two main conditions: emphysema, where the air sacs (alveoli) are damaged, and chronic bronchitis, which involves long-term inflammation of the airways with increased mucus production. The primary cause is long-term exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter, most often from cigarette smoke, but also from air pollution and occupational dusts.
symptoms: Progressive shortness of breath, especially during physical activities
Wheezing or a whistling sound when breathing
A persistent chronic cough that may produce clear, white, yellow, or greenish mucus
Frequent respiratory infections like colds or the flu
Chest tightness
Lack of energy and unintended weight loss in later stages
Blueness of the lips or fingernail beds (cyanosis)
prevention: The most critical step is to never start smoking or to quit smoking.
Avoid secondhand smoke and limit exposure to air pollution and occupational dusts by using protective equipment.
Get regular flu and pneumococcal vaccinations to prevent infections that can worsen COPD.
Regular exercise to improve respiratory muscle strength.
treatment: Bronchodilators (both short-acting and long-acting) to relax airway muscles
Inhaled or oral steroids to reduce airway inflammation
Combination inhalers
Pulmonary rehabilitation programs to improve breathing and quality of life
Oxygen therapy for individuals with low blood oxygen levels
Antibiotics to treat bacterial infections during flare-ups
In severe cases, lung volume reduction surgery or a lung transplant.

name: Coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever)
description: Coccidioidomycosis, commonly known as Valley Fever, is an infection caused by inhaling the airborne spores of the fungus *Coccidioides*, which thrives in the dry, alkaline soil of arid regions like the southwestern United States and parts of Latin America. While most infections are asymptomatic or result in mild, self-resolving flu-like symptoms, a small percentage can develop into severe or chronic pneumonia. In rare cases, especially in immunocompromised individuals, the infection can disseminate (spread) beyond the lungs to the skin, bones, joints, and nervous system (meningitis), requiring long-term antifungal treatment.
symptoms: Fatigue and body aches
Fever, chills, and night sweats
A persistent cough, sometimes with chest pain
A red, spotty rash, sometimes with painful nodules on the legs
Headache and joint pain
Shortness of breath
prevention: Avoid activities that stir up large amounts of dust in endemic areas, such as digging or construction.
Wear N95 respirator masks when exposure to dust is unavoidable.
Stay indoors and close windows during dust storms.
Use air filtration systems in homes within endemic regions.
treatment: Most mild cases resolve on their own with rest and supportive care.
For moderate to severe or disseminated infections, a course of antifungal medications (like fluconazole or itraconazole) is prescribed, sometimes for many months.
In life-threatening cases, intravenous antifungal drugs such as Amphotericin B may be used.
Symptom management for fever and pain.

name: Conjunctivitis
description: Conjunctivitis, widely known as 'pink eye,' is the inflammation of the conjunctiva, the transparent membrane that lines the eyelid and covers the white part of the eyeball. This inflammation makes blood vessels more visible, giving the eye a pink or reddish appearance. It is commonly caused by viral or bacterial infections (both highly contagious), allergies (not contagious), or chemical irritants. Most cases are mild and resolve within a week or two with proper hygiene and care, but bacterial conjunctivitis may require antibiotic treatment.
symptoms: Redness or pinkness in one or both eyes
Itching, irritation, or a gritty feeling
A discharge that can be watery (viral/allergic) or thick and pus-like (bacterial), forming a crust during sleep
Increased tear production
Swollen eyelids
Sensitivity to bright light (photophobia)
prevention: Practice frequent and thorough handwashing, especially after touching your eyes.
Avoid touching or rubbing your eyes.
Use clean towels and washcloths daily, and do not share them.
Do not share personal items like eye makeup, pillows, or eyeglasses.
If you have allergies, try to avoid known triggers.
treatment: Antibiotic eye drops or ointments for bacterial conjunctivitis.
Lubricating eye drops (artificial tears) to relieve dryness and irritation.
Antihistamine eye drops for allergic conjunctivitis.
Applying cold or warm compresses to soothe the eyes.
Viral conjunctivitis typically resolves on its own as the body fights the virus.

name: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
description: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) is the most common type of heart disease. It develops when the coronary arteries, the major blood vessels that supply the heart muscle with blood, oxygen, and nutrients, become damaged or diseased. This damage is most often caused by atherosclerosis, a process where cholesterol-containing deposits (plaque) build up, narrowing the arteries. This narrowing reduces blood flow, which can cause chest pain (angina). If a plaque ruptures, a blood clot can form and completely block the artery, leading to a heart attack. The rising prevalence of CAD in India is linked to lifestyle changes, including diet, physical inactivity, and stress.
symptoms: Chest pain, pressure, or tightness (angina), often triggered by physical or emotional stress
Shortness of breath, especially with exertion
Unusual fatigue or weakness
Pain in the neck, jaw, throat, upper abdomen, or back
A heart attack can be the first sign, with symptoms like crushing chest pain, sweating, and dizziness.
prevention: Eat a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fat, trans fat, and sodium.
Engage in regular physical exercise.
Maintain a healthy weight.
Effectively manage blood pressure, cholesterol, and diabetes.
Quit smoking and avoid secondhand smoke.
Manage stress effectively.
treatment: Aggressive lifestyle changes (diet, exercise).
Medications such as statins to lower cholesterol, beta-blockers to lower blood pressure, aspirin to prevent clots, and nitroglycerin for chest pain.
Procedures like angioplasty with stenting to open narrowed arteries.
Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery to reroute blood flow around blocked arteries.

name: Crohn's Disease
description: Crohn's disease is a chronic type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes inflammation and irritation in the digestive tract. Unlike ulcerative colitis, which only affects the colon, Crohn's can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to the anus, and the inflammation can penetrate deep into the layers of bowel tissue. The disease presents in periods of active illness (flare-ups) and periods of remission. The exact cause is unknown but is thought to involve a combination of genetic, environmental, and immune system factors.
symptoms: Persistent diarrhea, which may be bloody
Abdominal pain, cramping, and bloating
Fever and fatigue
Unexplained weight loss and reduced appetite
Mouth sores
Pain or drainage near the anus due to inflammation or a fistula
prevention: There is no known way to prevent Crohn's disease.
Management focuses on preventing flare-ups by avoiding triggers.
Quitting smoking is crucial as it is a major risk factor for developing and worsening the disease.
Managing stress and following a diet plan recommended by a healthcare professional.
treatment: Anti-inflammatory drugs like corticosteroids and aminosalicylates (5-ASAs).
Immune system suppressors to reduce inflammation.
Biologic therapies that target specific proteins in the immune system.
Nutritional therapy, including special diets or IV nutrition.
Surgery to remove damaged portions of the digestive tract is often necessary at some point.

name: Cystic Fibrosis
description: Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a progressive, inherited genetic disorder that primarily affects the lungs, pancreas, and other organs. The condition is caused by a faulty gene that affects the cells that produce mucus, sweat, and digestive juices. In people with CF, these secreted fluids become thick and sticky instead of thin and slippery. This thick mucus clogs tubes, ducts, and passageways, particularly in the lungs and pancreas, leading to severe respiratory infections and digestive problems. Though there is no cure, advancements in care have significantly improved life expectancy and quality of life.
symptoms: A persistent cough that produces thick mucus (sputum)
Wheezing and shortness of breath
Poor weight gain and growth despite a good appetite
Frequent lung infections, including pneumonia and bronchitis
Greasy, bulky stools or difficulty with bowel movements
Very salty-tasting skin
prevention: As a genetic disease, CF cannot be prevented.
Genetic carrier screening and counseling are available for prospective parents with a family history of CF.
Newborn screening programs allow for early diagnosis and prompt initiation of treatment to improve outcomes.
treatment: Airway clearance techniques (e.g., chest physiotherapy) to loosen mucus.
Inhaled medicines, including mucus thinners and bronchodilators.
CFTR modulator therapies that target the underlying cause of the disease.
Pancreatic enzyme supplements to aid digestion and nutritional support.
Antibiotics to treat and prevent lung infections.

name: Cystitis
description: Cystitis is the medical term for inflammation of the bladder. It is most often caused by a bacterial infection and is a common type of urinary tract infection (UTI). While it can affect anyone, it is particularly common in women due to their anatomy. Symptoms include a persistent urge to urinate, a burning sensation during urination, and pelvic discomfort. While usually more of an annoyance than a serious concern, it can lead to a more severe kidney infection if left untreated.
symptoms: A burning or painful sensation during urination (dysuria)
A strong, persistent urge to urinate (urgency)
Passing frequent, small amounts of urine
Blood in the urine (hematuria)
Cloudy or strong-smelling urine
Pelvic pain or pressure in the lower abdomen
prevention: Drink plenty of fluids, especially water, to flush out bacteria.
Wipe from front to back after a bowel movement to prevent bacterial spread.
Urinate soon after sexual intercourse.
Avoid irritating feminine products like douches or sprays.
Take showers instead of baths.
treatment: A course of antibiotics is the standard treatment for bacterial cystitis.
Pain relief medication to manage discomfort.
Drinking plenty of water to help flush the infection out.
Using a heating pad on the abdomen can soothe pain.
Lifestyle changes and home remedies for recurrent cases.

name: Dengue Fever
description: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection found in tropical and sub-tropical climates worldwide. Transmitted by female *Aedes aegypti* mosquitoes, it can cause a wide spectrum of illness, from a mild flu-like syndrome to a severe, potentially fatal condition called severe dengue (or dengue hemorrhagic fever). There are four distinct, but closely related, serotypes of the virus that cause dengue. Recovery from infection by one provides lifelong immunity against that serotype but only temporary immunity against the others.
symptoms: Sudden, high fever (up to 104°F or 40°C)
Severe headache, often with pain behind the eyes
Severe joint and muscle pain (giving it the nickname 'breakbone fever')
A characteristic skin rash
Nausea, vomiting, and fatigue
Warning signs of severe dengue include severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, and bleeding from the nose or gums.
prevention: Eliminate mosquito breeding sites by removing standing water from containers like tires, flowerpots, and buckets.
Use mosquito repellents containing DEET, picaridin, or oil of lemon eucalyptus.
Wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants, especially during peak mosquito biting times (early morning and late afternoon).
Use screens on windows and doors and sleep under mosquito nets.
treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment for dengue.
Care is supportive, focusing on relieving symptoms.
Maintain adequate hydration by drinking plenty of fluids.
Use pain relievers like acetaminophen (paracetamol). Avoid NSAIDs like ibuprofen and aspirin as they can increase bleeding risk.
Hospitalization is required for severe dengue for fluid management and close monitoring.

name: Dental Caries (Tooth Decay)
description: Dental caries, commonly known as cavities or tooth decay, is the breakdown of teeth due to acids made by bacteria. Bacteria in dental plaque convert sugars in food into acids, which demineralize the tooth's hard tissues (enamel and dentin). This is one of the most common chronic diseases globally and a significant health issue in India, largely driven by high consumption of sugary foods and beverages combined with inadequate oral hygiene. If left untreated, caries can progress, leading to severe pain, infection (abscess), and eventual tooth loss.
symptoms: Spontaneous toothache or pain that occurs without any apparent cause
Tooth sensitivity to hot, cold, or sweet substances
Visible holes, pits, or cavities in the teeth
Brown, black, or white staining on any surface of a tooth
Pain when you bite down
prevention: Brush teeth at least twice a day with a fluoride toothpaste.
Clean between your teeth daily with dental floss.
Limit snacking and consumption of sugary foods and drinks.
Visit your dentist regularly for professional cleanings and oral exams.
Consider dental sealants and fluoride treatments for added protection.
treatment: Dental fillings to restore the tooth after removing the decayed portion.
Crowns for more extensively damaged teeth.
Root canal therapy if the decay has reached the inner pulp of the tooth.
Tooth extraction if the tooth is too damaged to be saved.
Fluoride treatments to help remineralize early-stage decay.

name: Depression
description: Major Depressive Disorder, commonly known as depression, is a serious mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness, emptiness, and a loss of interest or pleasure in activities once enjoyed. It's more than just feeling sad; it affects how you feel, think, and behave, and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems. In India, depression is a major public health concern, often under-diagnosed and under-treated due to social stigma and lack of awareness. Effective treatments are available, and seeking help is a sign of strength.
symptoms: Persistent sad, anxious, or 'empty' mood
Loss of interest or pleasure in hobbies and activities
Significant changes in sleep patterns (insomnia or oversleeping) or appetite
Pervasive fatigue or loss of energy
Feelings of worthlessness, hopelessness, or guilt
Difficulty concentrating, remembering, or making decisions
Thoughts of death or suicide
prevention: While not always preventable, certain strategies can help manage symptoms and reduce risk.
Learn and practice stress management and resilience techniques.
Engage in regular physical exercise and maintain a balanced diet.
Build and maintain a strong social support system of friends and family.
Seek professional help at the earliest signs of a problem to prevent it from worsening.
treatment: Psychotherapy (talk therapy), such as Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) or Interpersonal Therapy (IPT).
Antidepressant medications (e.g., SSRIs, SNRIs).
Lifestyle modifications including regular exercise, a healthy diet, and a consistent sleep schedule.
Joining support groups to connect with others facing similar challenges.
In severe cases, brain stimulation therapies like ECT may be considered.

name: Dermatomyositis
description: Dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease that is part of a group of muscle diseases known as inflammatory myopathies. It is characterized by progressive muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. The condition can affect both adults and children and is considered an autoimmune disease, where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues. The rash often appears on the face, eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, chest, and back. The muscle weakness typically affects the muscles closest to the trunk, such as those in the hips, thighs, shoulders, and upper arms.
symptoms: Progressive muscle weakness, making activities like climbing stairs or lifting objects difficult
A dusky red or purplish (heliotrope) skin rash, often on the eyelids
Red or purple bumps over the knuckles (Gottron's papules)
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) and a hoarse voice
Fatigue, fever, and weight loss
Hardened calcium deposits under the skin (calcinosis), especially in children
prevention: There is no known way to prevent dermatomyositis.
Protecting the skin from sun exposure is crucial as it can worsen the rash.
Maintaining a healthy immune system through a balanced lifestyle.
Early diagnosis and treatment are key to managing the disease and preventing complications.
treatment: Corticosteroids like prednisone to suppress the immune system and reduce inflammation.
Immunosuppressant drugs to reduce reliance on steroids.
Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) therapy.
Physical therapy to maintain muscle strength and flexibility.
Topical creams for the skin rash.

name: Diabetes
description: Diabetes mellitus is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by high levels of blood glucose (sugar). This occurs because the body either does not produce enough insulin (Type 1 diabetes) or cannot effectively use the insulin it does produce (Type 2 diabetes). Insulin is a hormone that regulates blood sugar. Uncontrolled high blood sugar over time can lead to serious damage to many of the body's systems, especially the nerves, blood vessels, eyes, kidneys, and heart. Gestational diabetes is a temporary type that occurs during pregnancy.
symptoms: Frequent urination (polyuria)
Increased thirst (polydipsia) and hunger (polyphagia)
Unexplained weight loss
Persistent fatigue and lack of energy
Blurred vision
Slow-healing sores or frequent infections
prevention: Maintain a healthy diet, limiting sugar and processed carbohydrates.
Engage in regular physical activity.
Maintain a healthy body weight.
Avoid smoking and limit alcohol intake.
Regularly monitor blood sugar levels, especially if you have risk factors like a family history or obesity.
treatment: For Type 1: Insulin therapy is essential (injections or insulin pump).
For Type 2: Oral medications, injectable non-insulin medications, and sometimes insulin.
Comprehensive lifestyle management including diet, exercise, and weight control.
Regular blood sugar monitoring to manage the condition effectively.
Regular checkups for eyes, kidneys, and feet to prevent complications.

name: Diabetic Retinopathy
description: Diabetic retinopathy is a serious eye complication of diabetes and a leading cause of blindness in working-age adults. It is caused by long-term damage to the blood vessels of the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. High blood sugar levels can cause these blood vessels to leak fluid or even close off, obstructing blood flow. In response, the eye may grow new, abnormal blood vessels. These changes can damage the retina and lead to progressive vision loss.
symptoms: Often no symptoms in the early stages.
Floaters, or dark spots and strings, in your vision.
Blurred or fluctuating vision.
Impaired color vision.
Dark or empty areas in your vision.
Sudden and total vision loss.
prevention: The most critical step is diligent management of blood sugar, blood pressure, and cholesterol levels.
Attend regular, comprehensive dilated eye exams at least once a year.
Quit smoking, as it increases the risk of developing retinopathy.
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise.
treatment: In early stages, good diabetes control can slow progression.
For advanced stages, treatments include:
Laser treatment (photocoagulation) to seal or destroy leaking blood vessels.
Injections of anti-VEGF medication into the eye to reduce swelling and abnormal vessel growth.
Vitrectomy surgery to remove blood and scar tissue from the eye.

name: Diphtheria
description: Diphtheria is a serious bacterial infection caused by *Corynebacterium diphtheriae* that affects the mucous membranes of the throat and nose. The bacteria produce a toxin that can cause a thick, gray coating to form in the throat, which can block airways and make breathing difficult. The toxin can also spread through the bloodstream and cause damage to the heart, nerves, and kidneys. Thanks to widespread vaccination, diphtheria is now rare in many parts of the world, but it can be fatal if left untreated.
symptoms: A thick, gray membrane covering the throat and tonsils
A severe sore throat and hoarseness
Fever and chills
Swollen glands (bull neck)
Weakness, fatigue, and rapid heart rate
Difficulty breathing or rapid breathing
prevention: The most effective prevention is vaccination with the DTaP vaccine (diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis).
Booster shots are needed throughout life to maintain immunity.
Practicing good hygiene and avoiding close contact with infected individuals can also help.
treatment: Immediate administration of a diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize the toxin.
A course of antibiotics, such as penicillin or erythromycin, to kill the bacteria.
Supportive care in a hospital setting, which may include breathing support.
Isolation to prevent the spread of the infection to others.

name: Dysentery
description: Dysentery is a severe intestinal infection characterized by inflammation of the intestines, particularly the colon. It results in severe diarrhea containing blood and mucus. The two main causes are the bacterium *Shigella* (shigellosis) and the amoeba *Entamoeba histolytica* (amoebiasis). The infection is typically spread through fecal-oral transmission via contaminated food, water, or poor hygiene. It is particularly dangerous for young children and the elderly due to the risk of severe dehydration and other complications.
symptoms: Frequent, watery diarrhea often containing blood and/or mucus
Severe abdominal cramps and pain
Fever and chills
Nausea and vomiting
A feeling of incomplete defecation (tenesmus)
prevention: Drink only purified or boiled water.
Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water, especially after using the toilet and before handling food.
Cook food properly and avoid raw vegetables or fruits that cannot be peeled.
Maintain good sanitation and safe sewage disposal.
treatment: Rehydration is critical. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is used to replace lost fluids and electrolytes.
For bacterial dysentery (shigellosis), antibiotics may be prescribed to shorten the illness.
For amoebic dysentery, specific anti-amoebic medications are required.
Pain relievers can help with cramps, but some anti-diarrheal medicines should be avoided.

name: Eczema
description: Eczema, also known as atopic dermatitis, is a chronic, non-contagious inflammatory skin condition that results in itchy, red, swollen, and cracked skin. It is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, often involving a compromised skin barrier and an overactive immune system. In India's varied climate, flare-ups can be triggered by allergens, dry weather, sweat, or stress. It most commonly appears in childhood but can persist into adulthood. Effective management involves consistent skincare and avoiding triggers.
symptoms: Intense itching (pruritus), which is often worse at night
Dry, sensitive skin
Red to brownish-gray patches, especially on the hands, feet, ankles, wrists, neck, and inside the bends of the elbows and knees
Small, raised bumps, which may leak fluid and crust over when scratched
Thickened, cracked, or scaly skin
prevention: Moisturize your skin at least twice a day to maintain the skin barrier.
Identify and avoid personal triggers like certain fabrics, soaps, or foods.
Use mild, non-soap cleansers and take short, lukewarm baths or showers.
Pat skin dry gently after bathing, leaving it slightly damp before applying moisturizer.
treatment: Topical corticosteroids and calcineurin inhibitors to control inflammation and itching.
Oral antihistamines to help reduce severe itching.
Wet wrap therapy for severe flare-ups.
Phototherapy (light therapy) using ultraviolet light.
Lifestyle management and consistent moisturizing are key.

name: Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis)
description: Atopic dermatitis is the most common form of eczema, a chronic condition that causes the skin to become inflamed, red, dry, and intensely itchy. It typically begins in childhood and is often associated with a personal or family history of other atopic diseases like asthma and hay fever. The condition is characterized by periods of flare-ups, where symptoms worsen, followed by periods of remission. Triggers can include environmental allergens, irritants, stress, and climate changes. There is no cure, but treatment focuses on healing the skin and preventing flares.
symptoms: Severe itching, which can disrupt sleep and daily activities
Dry, scaly, or thickened skin patches
Red or inflamed skin, which may appear different on various skin tones
Oozing or crusting from small bumps, especially after scratching
Raw, sensitive, or swollen skin from scratching
prevention: Follow a consistent daily bathing and moisturizing routine.
Avoid known triggers such as harsh soaps, detergents, certain fabrics (like wool), and specific allergens.
Keep fingernails short to minimize skin damage from scratching.
Manage stress through techniques like meditation or yoga.
treatment: Application of topical corticosteroid creams or ointments to reduce inflammation.
Antihistamine pills to help control itching.
Phototherapy, where skin is exposed to controlled amounts of natural or artificial light.
Biologic drugs for more severe, difficult-to-treat cases.
Calcineurin inhibitors (topical) as an alternative to steroids.

name: Eczema (Dermatitis)
description: Dermatitis is a general term for skin inflammation, with eczema being the most common type. It results in patches of skin that are dry, itchy, red, and inflamed. There are various types, including atopic dermatitis (often genetic), contact dermatitis (caused by touching an irritant or allergen), and seborrheic dermatitis (dandruff). Scratching the itchy areas can lead to further irritation, skin breakdown, and an increased risk of bacterial infection. Management focuses on identifying the type of dermatitis, avoiding triggers, and using medications to control symptoms.
symptoms: Dry, chapped skin
Persistent itching
Red patches or rashes
Skin irritation, burning, or stinging
Blisters that may weep and crust over
Swelling of the affected area
prevention: Moisturize your skin daily with a gentle, fragrance-free moisturizer.
Avoid harsh soaps, detergents, and chemicals.
Identify and avoid allergens or irritants that cause contact dermatitis.
Wear soft, breathable fabrics like cotton.
Minimize exposure to known environmental allergens.
treatment: Emollients and moisturizers to hydrate the skin.
Topical steroid creams or ointments to reduce inflammation.
Oral or topical antihistamines to relieve itching.
Antibiotics if the skin becomes infected.
For contact dermatitis, strict avoidance of the identified trigger is essential.

name: Endocarditis
description: Endocarditis is a rare but potentially fatal infection of the endocardium, which is the inner lining of the heart's chambers and valves. It most commonly occurs when bacteria, fungi, or other germs from another part of your body, such as your mouth, spread through your bloodstream and attach to damaged areas in your heart. People with pre-existing heart valve conditions, artificial heart valves, or a history of endocarditis are at higher risk. Prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial to prevent severe damage to the heart valves and other life-threatening complications.
symptoms: Flu-like symptoms, such as fever, chills, and fatigue
A new or changed heart murmur
Aching joints and muscles
Shortness of breath and a persistent cough
Swelling in your feet, legs, or abdomen
Unexplained weight loss and night sweats
Tiny spots on the skin, under the fingernails, or in the eyes
prevention: Maintain excellent oral hygiene, including regular dental check-ups, to prevent bacteria from entering the bloodstream.
Avoid procedures that could lead to skin infections, like body piercings or tattoos.
Seek prompt medical treatment for any bacterial infections.
High-risk individuals may need preventive antibiotics before certain dental or medical procedures.
treatment: A long course of high-dose intravenous (IV) antibiotics, usually administered in a hospital for several weeks.
Regular monitoring with blood tests and echocardiograms.
In cases where the infection has severely damaged the heart valves, surgery may be necessary to repair or replace the affected valves.

name: Endometriosis
description: Endometriosis is a chronic and often painful gynecological disorder in which tissue similar to the endometrium—the tissue that normally lines the inside of the uterus—grows outside the uterus. This misplaced tissue can be found on the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and the tissues lining the pelvis. It behaves like endometrial tissue, thickening, breaking down, and bleeding with each menstrual cycle. Because this tissue has no way to exit the body, it becomes trapped, leading to irritation, scar formation (adhesions), and severe pain, and can also contribute to fertility problems.
symptoms: Extremely painful menstrual periods (dysmenorrhea)
Pain during or after sexual intercourse
Chronic pain in the lower back and pelvis
Excessive or heavy menstrual bleeding
Infertility or difficulty getting pregnant
Painful bowel movements or urination, especially during menstrual periods.
prevention: There is no known way to prevent endometriosis.
Some studies suggest that managing estrogen levels through lifestyle choices like regular exercise and avoiding excessive alcohol and caffeine might lower the risk, but this is not definitive.
Early diagnosis and management can help slow the progression and manage symptoms.
treatment: Pain medication, including over-the-counter NSAIDs.
Hormone therapy, such as birth control pills or GnRH agonists, to slow tissue growth and prevent new implants.
Laparoscopic surgery to diagnose and remove endometrial implants and scar tissue.
In severe cases where fertility is not a concern, a hysterectomy with removal of the ovaries may be considered.

name: Epilepsy
description: Epilepsy is a chronic central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. A person is diagnosed with epilepsy if they have two or more unprovoked seizures. Seizure types can vary widely. In India, epilepsy carries a significant social stigma, often leading to delayed diagnosis and inadequate treatment. However, with proper anti-seizure medications, most people with epilepsy can control their seizures and lead full, productive lives.
symptoms: Recurrent seizures, which can manifest as:
Temporary confusion or a staring spell
Uncontrollable jerking movements of the arms and legs (convulsions)
Loss of consciousness or awareness
Psychic symptoms such as fear, anxiety, or déjà vu
Strange sensations and emotions
prevention: Preventing traumatic brain injuries by wearing helmets and seatbelts.
Good prenatal care to reduce the risk of brain damage in newborns.
Promptly treating infections of the brain like meningitis.
Lowering the risk of stroke through cardiovascular health management.
treatment: Anti-seizure (antiepileptic) medications are the most common form of treatment.
Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) or deep brain stimulation (DBS) for medication-resistant cases.
A ketogenic diet can be effective, especially for some children.
In some cases, surgery to remove the area of the brain causing seizures.
Lifestyle adjustments like getting enough sleep and avoiding seizure triggers.

name: Erysipelas
description: Erysipelas is a superficial bacterial skin infection that involves the upper layers of the skin and lymphatics. It is most often caused by *Streptococcus* bacteria entering the skin through a cut, sore, or break. The infection results in a well-defined, raised, and intensely red patch of skin that is painful and warm to the touch. It most commonly affects the legs or face. Erysipelas can spread rapidly and is often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever and chills, requiring prompt antibiotic treatment to prevent complications.
symptoms: A fiery red, swollen, and warm area of skin with a sharply defined border
Pain and tenderness in the affected area
Sudden onset of fever and chills
A general feeling of being unwell (malaise)
Blisters may form on the affected skin in severe cases
Swollen lymph nodes near the infected area
prevention: Maintain good skin hygiene.
Clean all cuts, scrapes, and insect bites thoroughly and promptly.
Treat underlying conditions that cause skin breaks, like athlete's foot or eczema.
Keep skin well-moisturized to prevent cracking.
Manage conditions like lymphedema or venous insufficiency.
treatment: A course of oral or intravenous (IV) antibiotics, typically penicillin, is the primary treatment.
Pain relievers for discomfort and fever.
Keeping the affected limb elevated to reduce swelling.
Adequate hydration and rest.
Hospitalization may be necessary for severe cases or if the infection spreads rapidly.

name: Fabry Disease
description: Fabry disease is a rare, inherited lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A. This enzyme deficiency leads to the harmful buildup of a fatty substance known as globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) in cells throughout the body, including in the skin, kidneys, heart, and nervous system. This progressive buildup causes a wide range of debilitating symptoms and can lead to organ damage and life-threatening complications over time. It is an X-linked genetic disorder, meaning it affects males more severely than females.
symptoms: Episodes of severe burning pain in the hands and feet (acroparesthesias)
A dark red or purplish skin rash (angiokeratomas)
Reduced ability to sweat (hypohidrosis)
Gastrointestinal issues like abdominal pain and diarrhea
Progressive kidney disease, heart problems (cardiomyopathy), and an increased risk of stroke
prevention: As a genetic condition, it cannot be prevented.
Genetic counseling and carrier screening are crucial for families with a known history of the disease.
Early diagnosis through newborn screening can allow for prompt initiation of treatment to slow disease progression.
treatment: Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) is the primary treatment, which involves regular infusions of the missing enzyme.
Chaperone therapy (for certain genetic mutations) which helps the body's own enzyme work more effectively.
Medications to manage specific symptoms like pain, kidney problems, and heart conditions.
Regular monitoring of organ function.

name: Fibromyalgia
description: Fibromyalgia is a complex chronic disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, accompanied by profound fatigue, sleep disturbances, memory issues, and mood swings. It is believed that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting how the brain and spinal cord process pain signals (central sensitization). Symptoms often begin after a physical trauma, surgery, infection, or significant psychological stress. In other cases, symptoms gradually accumulate over time with no single triggering event. It is more common in women.
symptoms: Widespread, dull, aching pain that has lasted for at least three months
Severe fatigue and a feeling of being drained of energy, even after sleeping
Cognitive difficulties, often referred to as 'fibro fog,' which impairs focus, attention, and concentration
Morning stiffness
Headaches, including migraines
Symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
prevention: There is no known way to prevent fibromyalgia.
Managing stress, maintaining a regular sleep schedule, and engaging in gentle, regular exercise can help manage symptoms and may reduce the severity of flare-ups.
treatment: A multi-faceted approach is most effective:
Medications including pain relievers, antidepressants, and anti-seizure drugs to help control symptoms.
Physical and occupational therapy to improve strength and reduce stress on the body.
Counseling, such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), to learn coping strategies.
Stress-reduction measures like yoga, meditation, and tai chi.
Lifestyle changes focusing on sleep hygiene and gentle exercise.

name: Filariasis
description: Lymphatic filariasis, commonly known as elephantiasis, is a neglected tropical disease caused by parasitic, thread-like worms transmitted to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes. The adult worms live in the human lymphatic system, disrupting its function and leading to chronic, disfiguring swelling (lymphedema). The disease can cause immense pain, severe disability, and social stigma. It is a major public health problem in many parts of the world, including India.
symptoms: Many people are asymptomatic but still harbor the parasite and contribute to its spread.
Recurrent episodes of fever and painful inflammation of lymph nodes (adenolymphangitis).
Chronic swelling of the limbs, genitals, or breasts (lymphedema).
In its most severe form, elephantiasis, the limbs or other body parts become enormously swollen and the skin thick and hard.
In men, swelling of the scrotum (hydrocele) is common.
prevention: Mass Drug Administration (MDA) programs in endemic areas, where entire communities are treated with preventive medications annually.
Effective vector control measures to reduce the mosquito population.
Using personal protective measures like mosquito nets and repellents.
Maintaining good hygiene to prevent secondary infections in affected limbs.
treatment: Antifilarial medications (like albendazole and diethylcarbamazine) to kill the microscopic worms and prevent transmission.
Careful management of lymphedema through hygiene, exercise, and elevation of affected limbs.
Surgical intervention for conditions like hydrocele.
Supportive care to manage pain and prevent secondary bacterial infections.

name: Frozen Shoulder (Adhesive Capsulitis)
description: Frozen shoulder, medically known as adhesive capsulitis, is a condition characterized by significant pain and stiffness in the shoulder joint, leading to a severe loss of motion. It occurs when the strong connective tissue surrounding the shoulder joint (the capsule) becomes thick, stiff, and inflamed. The condition typically develops slowly and progresses through three stages: freezing (pain increases, motion decreases), frozen (pain may lessen, but stiffness remains), and thawing (range of motion slowly improves). The entire process can last from one to three years.
symptoms: Dull or aching pain in the shoulder, often worse at night
Progressive stiffness and a significant decrease in the shoulder's active and passive range of motion
Inability to perform daily activities like reaching overhead or behind the back
prevention: While the exact cause is often unknown, prevention focuses on maintaining shoulder mobility.
Perform regular, gentle range-of-motion and stretching exercises for the shoulder.
For individuals with a shoulder injury or who are immobilized (e.g., after surgery), it's crucial to begin mobilization and physical therapy as soon as medically advised.
treatment: Pain relievers and anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs).
Physical therapy is the cornerstone of treatment, focusing on stretching exercises to restore motion.
Corticosteroid injections into the shoulder joint to reduce inflammation and pain.
In persistent cases, procedures like joint distension (injecting sterile water to stretch the capsule) or surgery (arthroscopic capsular release) may be considered.

name: Gallstones
description: Gallstones are hardened deposits of digestive fluid that can form in the gallbladder, a small organ situated beneath the liver. The gallbladder stores bile, a digestive fluid produced in the liver. Gallstones can range in size from as small as a grain of sand to as large as a golf ball. They form when there are imbalances in the substances that make up bile, such as too much cholesterol or too much bilirubin. Many people with gallstones have no symptoms, but if a gallstone lodges in a duct and causes a blockage, it can result in a sudden, intense abdominal pain known as a biliary colic or gallstone attack.
symptoms: Sudden and rapidly intensifying pain in the upper right portion or center of the abdomen
Pain between the shoulder blades or in the right shoulder
Nausea or vomiting
Indigestion, bloating, and gas after eating, especially fatty foods
Jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes) if a stone blocks the common bile duct.
prevention: Maintain a healthy weight, as obesity is a major risk factor.
Avoid rapid weight loss.
Eat a well-balanced, high-fiber diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
Limit foods high in cholesterol and unhealthy fats.
Engage in regular physical exercise.
treatment: For asymptomatic gallstones, treatment is often not necessary.
For symptomatic gallstones, the most common treatment is surgical removal of the gallbladder (cholecystectomy).
Medications to dissolve cholesterol gallstones, though this is used infrequently as it can take years and stones may reform.
Pain management during a gallstone attack.
Endoscopic procedures (ERCP) to remove stones blocking the bile ducts.

name: Gastroenteritis
description: Gastroenteritis, often referred to as 'stomach flu,' is an inflammation of the lining of the stomach and intestines. It is typically caused by viral (like norovirus or rotavirus), bacterial (like Salmonella or E. coli), or parasitic infections. The illness is highly contagious and spreads easily through contact with an infected person or by consuming contaminated food or water, a common issue in many parts of India. While usually self-limiting and lasting a few days, the main danger is dehydration from fluid loss due to vomiting and diarrhea, which can be particularly severe in children, the elderly, and those with weakened immune systems.
symptoms: Watery diarrhea
Nausea and vomiting
Abdominal cramps and pain
Low-grade fever and chills
Headache and muscle aches
prevention: Wash hands thoroughly and frequently with soap and water.
Drink only safe, purified, or boiled water.
Avoid consuming raw or undercooked food, and be cautious with street food from unhygienic sources.
Practice proper food hygiene, including washing fruits and vegetables well.
Vaccination against rotavirus is available for infants.
treatment: The primary goal is to prevent dehydration.
Increase fluid intake with water, clear broths, or an Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS).
Get plenty of rest to allow the body to recover.
Gradually reintroduce bland, easy-to-digest foods (like bananas, rice, toast).
Antibiotics are only effective for certain types of bacterial gastroenteritis and are prescribed by a doctor.
Medical care and IV fluids are needed for severe dehydration.

name: Glaucoma
description: Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, which is vital for vision as it transmits visual information from the eye to the brain. This damage is often caused by abnormally high pressure inside the eye (intraocular pressure). Glaucoma is one of the leading causes of irreversible blindness for people over the age of 60. It can develop gradually over many years (open-angle glaucoma) or appear suddenly (angle-closure glaucoma). Because it often has no early symptoms, regular comprehensive eye exams are crucial for early detection and treatment to protect vision.
symptoms: Open-angle glaucoma: Often no symptoms in early stages. Gradual loss of peripheral (side) vision, usually in both eyes; tunnel vision in advanced stages.
Angle-closure glaucoma (acute): Severe eye pain, nausea and vomiting, sudden onset of visual disturbance (often in low light), blurred vision, halos around lights, and eye redness.
prevention: While it can't be completely prevented, early detection is key.
Get regular dilated eye examinations to detect glaucoma in its early stages.
Know your family's eye health history.
Protect your eyes from injury by wearing protective eyewear during sports or certain projects.
Control underlying conditions like diabetes and high blood pressure.
treatment: The goal is to lower intraocular pressure to prevent further optic nerve damage.
Prescription eye drops are the most common initial treatment.
Oral medications may also be prescribed.
Laser therapy (e.g., trabeculoplasty) to improve fluid drainage.
Surgical procedures (e.g., trabeculectomy or drainage devices) to create a new drainage channel for the eye.

name: Goiter
description: A goiter is an abnormal enlargement of the thyroid gland, the butterfly-shaped gland located at the base of the neck. Although a goiter is usually painless, a large one can cause a cough and make it difficult to swallow or breathe. The most common cause of goiters worldwide is a lack of iodine in the diet. In countries where iodized salt is common, goiters are more often due to other conditions, such as the over- or underproduction of thyroid hormones or nodules that develop in the gland itself.
symptoms: A visible swelling at the base of your neck
A feeling of tightness in your throat
A hoarse voice
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) or breathing (dyspnea)
Coughing
Symptoms of hyperthyroidism (weight loss, rapid heartbeat) or hypothyroidism (fatigue, weight gain) may also be present depending on the cause.
prevention: Ensure adequate iodine intake, most commonly by using iodized salt.
Consume iodine-rich foods such as seafood, seaweed, and dairy products.
Regular health checkups can help detect thyroid issues early.
Avoid excessive consumption of foods that can inhibit thyroid function (goitrogens), although this is rarely a cause in diets with adequate iodine.
treatment: Treatment depends on the size and cause of the goiter.
Watchful waiting if the goiter is small and not causing problems.
Iodine supplements for goiters caused by iodine deficiency.
Thyroid hormone replacement therapy for goiters associated with hypothyroidism.
Medications or radioactive iodine to treat goiters from hyperthyroidism.
Surgery (thyroidectomy) may be needed for very large goiters that cause compressive symptoms or are cancerous.

name: Gonorrhea
description: Gonorrhea is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium *Neisseria gonorrhoeae*. It can infect both men and women and commonly affects the warm, moist areas of the reproductive tract, including the urethra, cervix, uterus, and fallopian tubes. It can also infect the rectum, throat, and eyes. Many people infected with gonorrhea have no symptoms, making it easy to transmit unknowingly. If left untreated, it can lead to serious and permanent health problems, including pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) and infertility.
symptoms: In Men: Painful urination, pus-like discharge from the penis, pain or swelling in one testicle.
In Women: Often asymptomatic, but can include painful urination, increased vaginal discharge, vaginal bleeding between periods, and pelvic or abdominal pain.
Rectal infections may cause anal itching, discharge, or pain.
Throat infections usually cause a sore throat.
prevention: The most reliable way is to abstain from sex or be in a long-term, mutually monogamous relationship with an uninfected partner.
Consistent and correct use of condoms can significantly reduce the risk of transmission.
Get regular STI testing if you are sexually active, especially with new partners.
Avoid sharing sex toys unless they are cleaned or covered with a new condom.
treatment: Gonorrhea is treated with antibiotics. Due to increasing antibiotic resistance, the standard treatment often involves a dual therapy of an injection (ceftriaxone) and an oral medication (azithromycin or doxycycline).
It is crucial that sexual partners are also notified and treated to prevent reinfection and further spread.
Abstain from sexual contact during and for one week after completing treatment.

name: Gorlin Syndrome
description: Gorlin syndrome, also known as nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (NBCCS), is a rare inherited condition that affects many areas of the body and increases the risk of developing various cancerous and noncancerous tumors. The most characteristic features are the development of multiple basal cell carcinomas (a type of skin cancer) at a young age and jaw cysts called odontogenic keratocysts. Individuals with Gorlin syndrome require lifelong surveillance and proactive management to address the various health issues that can arise.
symptoms: Development of multiple basal cell carcinomas, often starting in adolescence or early adulthood.
Recurrent cysts in the jaws.
Distinctive facial features like a large head size (macrocephaly) and a prominent forehead.
Skeletal abnormalities such as fused or extra ribs.
Pits or depressions in the skin on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.
Increased risk for other tumors, like medulloblastoma (a type of brain cancer in children).
prevention: As a genetic disorder, it cannot be prevented.
Strict sun protection (sunscreen, protective clothing) is crucial to minimize the development of skin cancers.
Regular check-ups with a dermatologist and dentist are essential for early detection and treatment of skin cancers and jaw cysts.
Avoidance of radiation therapy if possible, as it can trigger the growth of more tumors.
treatment: Surgical removal or other treatments (topical creams, photodynamic therapy) for basal cell carcinomas.
Surgical removal of jaw cysts.
Treatment for other tumors as they arise.
Genetic counseling for affected individuals and their families is important for understanding the condition and its inheritance pattern.

name: Gout
description: Gout is a common and complex form of inflammatory arthritis characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness in the joints, often at the base of the big toe. It occurs when urate crystals accumulate in a joint, causing inflammation and intense pain. These crystals form when there are high levels of uric acid in the blood (hyperuricemia). Risk factors in India include diets rich in purines (red meat, seafood), alcohol consumption, obesity, and dehydration. Untreated gout can lead to recurrent attacks, joint damage, and kidney stones.
symptoms: Intense, sudden joint pain, most commonly affecting the big toe, but can occur in ankles, knees, elbows, wrists, and fingers.
Significant swelling, inflammation, and redness over the affected joint.
Extreme tenderness, where even the weight of a bedsheet can be intolerable.
Lingering discomfort that may last for days or weeks after a severe attack.
prevention: Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of water.
Limit consumption of purine-rich foods like red meat, organ meats, and certain seafood.
Limit or avoid alcohol, especially beer.
Maintain a healthy body weight through diet and regular exercise.
Limit consumption of sugary drinks and foods.
treatment: During an attack: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, or corticosteroids to reduce pain and inflammation.
For long-term management: Medications that either block uric acid production (like allopurinol) or improve its removal (like probenecid).
Consistent lifestyle and dietary changes are crucial for long-term control.

name: Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease (HFMD)
description: Hand, foot, and mouth disease is a mild but highly contagious viral infection common in infants and young children, typically under the age of 5. It is most often caused by the coxsackievirus. The illness is characterized by sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet. It spreads easily through person-to-person contact, respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes, and contact with contaminated surfaces. Outbreaks are common in childcare settings, especially in India. While uncomfortable, the illness is usually self-limiting and resolves within 7 to 10 days.
symptoms: Fever and sore throat
Painful, red, blister-like sores in the mouth (herpangina)
A non-itchy skin rash with red spots, sometimes with blisters, on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet
Rash may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks, or genital area
General feeling of being unwell (malaise) and loss of appetite
prevention: Frequent and thorough handwashing with soap and water is the best defense.
Regularly disinfect common areas, toys, and surfaces.
Avoid close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils with infected individuals.
Teach children good hygiene practices.
treatment: There is no specific treatment; care is supportive.
Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen for fever and pain.
Ensure adequate hydration by encouraging fluids, as mouth sores can make swallowing painful.
Topical oral anesthetics can help relieve mouth sore pain.
Rest and allowing the illness to run its course.

name: Hantavirus Infection
description: Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome (HPS) is a rare but severe and potentially fatal respiratory illness caused by infection with hantaviruses. These viruses are carried by certain species of rodents (like deer mice). Humans become infected primarily through the inhalation of aerosolized virus that is shed in rodent urine, droppings, or saliva. The infection does not spread from person to person. Early symptoms are flu-like, but the illness can rapidly progress to severe respiratory failure. Prompt medical attention is critical.
symptoms: Early Symptoms (1-5 days): Fever, chills, severe muscle aches, headaches, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting.
Late Symptoms (4-10 days later): Lungs fill with fluid, leading to severe shortness of breath, coughing, and a feeling of a tight band around the chest.
The condition can progress rapidly to respiratory failure and shock.
prevention: Rodent control is the primary strategy.
Seal up holes and gaps in homes or cabins to prevent rodents from entering.
Use traps to reduce rodent populations around living areas.
When cleaning areas with rodent droppings, wear gloves and a proper respirator, wet the area with disinfectant to avoid stirring up dust, and dispose of materials safely.
treatment: There is no specific cure or vaccine for hantavirus infection.
Treatment is supportive and must be administered in a hospital, often in an intensive care unit (ICU).
Care includes oxygen therapy and often mechanical ventilation to support breathing during the acute phase of respiratory distress.
Early recognition and admission to the hospital are crucial for improving outcomes.

name: Heat Stroke
description: Heat stroke is the most serious form of heat injury and is considered a medical emergency. It occurs when the body's temperature regulation system is overwhelmed by prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, causing the core body temperature to rise to 104°F (40°C) or higher. Common during intense Indian summers, it can cause damage to the brain, heart, kidneys, and muscles. If not treated immediately, heat stroke can be fatal. It particularly affects outdoor workers, athletes, young children, and the elderly.
symptoms: A core body temperature of 104°F (40°C) or higher
Altered mental state or behavior, such as confusion, agitation, slurred speech, or delirium
Hot, dry skin (in classic heatstroke) or heavy sweating (in exertional heatstroke)
Nausea and vomiting
Flushed skin and a rapid, throbbing headache
Rapid breathing and a racing heart rate
Seizures or loss of consciousness
prevention: Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids, especially water.
Avoid strenuous activities and direct sun exposure during the hottest parts of the day.
Wear lightweight, loose-fitting, and light-colored clothing.
Take frequent breaks in cool, shaded, or air-conditioned areas.
Never leave anyone in a parked car.
treatment: This is an emergency; call for immediate medical help.
While waiting for help, move the person to a cooler place.
Cool the person rapidly using whatever methods are available: immerse in a tub of cool water, spray with cool water, or place cool, wet cloths on the body.
Do not give the person anything to drink if they are confused or unconscious.
Emergency medical care will involve continued cooling and supportive treatment.

name: Hemophilia
description: Hemophilia is a rare, inherited bleeding disorder in which the blood does not clot properly. This is because the blood lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins, known as clotting factors. The two main types are Hemophilia A (deficiency of factor VIII) and Hemophilia B (deficiency of factor IX). The condition can lead to spontaneous bleeding or prolonged bleeding after an injury, surgery, or dental work. Bleeding into joints and muscles can cause chronic pain and permanent damage.
symptoms: Unexplained and excessive bleeding from cuts or injuries
Many large or deep bruises
Prolonged bleeding after surgery or tooth extraction
Pain, swelling, or tightness in joints (often knees, elbows, and ankles)
Blood in the urine or stool
Frequent and hard-to-stop nosebleeds
prevention: As a genetic disorder, hemophilia cannot be prevented.
Genetic counseling and testing are important for families with a history of the disorder to understand the risk of passing it on.
For individuals with hemophilia, preventing bleeding episodes involves avoiding activities with a high risk of injury and maintaining good dental hygiene to prevent gum bleeding.
treatment: The primary treatment is replacement therapy, which involves the infusion of the missing clotting factor concentrates into a vein.
Prophylactic infusions are given regularly to prevent bleeding.
Non-factor replacement therapies are newer treatments that work differently to help the blood clot.
Physical therapy to protect and strengthen joints.
Pain management for joint bleeds.

name: Hemorrhoids (Piles)
description: Hemorrhoids, also commonly known as piles, are swollen and inflamed veins in the anus and lower rectum. They can be compared to varicose veins and can develop either internally (inside the rectum) or externally (under the skin around the anus). They are a very common condition, often resulting from straining during bowel movements, chronic constipation or diarrhea, obesity, or pregnancy. While they can be uncomfortable and cause bleeding, they are usually not life-threatening and can often be managed with home treatments and lifestyle changes.
symptoms: Painless, bright red bleeding during bowel movements (often seen on toilet paper)
Itching, irritation, or swelling in the anal region
Pain or discomfort, particularly when sitting
A sensitive or painful lump near the anus (thrombosed external hemorrhoid)
A feeling of incomplete bowel evacuation
prevention: Eat a diet high in fiber (fruits, vegetables, whole grains) to soften stool.
Drink plenty of fluids throughout the day.
Avoid straining or holding your breath during bowel movements.
Go to the bathroom as soon as you feel the urge.
Engage in regular physical exercise to promote bowel regularity.
Avoid sitting for long periods, especially on the toilet.
treatment: Lifestyle and dietary changes to increase fiber and fluid intake.
Over-the-counter topical creams, ointments, or suppositories containing hydrocortisone or witch hazel.
Soaking in a warm bath (sitz bath) for 10-15 minutes several times a day.
Minimally invasive procedures like rubber band ligation or sclerotherapy.
In severe or persistent cases, surgical removal (hemorrhoidectomy) may be necessary.

name: Hepatitis A
description: Hepatitis A is a highly contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV). The virus is primarily spread through the fecal-oral route, which means it's typically transmitted by ingesting food or water contaminated with fecal matter from an infected person. It can also be spread through close personal contact. Unlike other forms of hepatitis, Hepatitis A does not cause chronic liver disease and is rarely fatal, but it can cause debilitating symptoms and, in rare cases, acute liver failure.
symptoms: Sudden onset of fatigue and malaise
Nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite
Abdominal pain or discomfort, especially in the area of the liver (upper right side)
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
Dark urine and clay-colored stools
Low-grade fever and joint pain
prevention: The most effective prevention is the Hepatitis A vaccine.
Practice good sanitation and hygiene, especially thorough handwashing with soap and water after using the bathroom and before preparing food.
Avoid consuming unclean or untreated water and be cautious with raw or undercooked food, especially when traveling.
Immune globulin can provide short-term protection if given before or shortly after exposure.
treatment: There is no specific treatment for Hepatitis A.
The body's immune system clears the virus on its own, and recovery can take several weeks or months.
Treatment is supportive, focusing on managing symptoms.
Get plenty of rest.
Maintain adequate nutrition and hydration.
Avoid alcohol and medications that can be harmful to the liver.

name: Hepatitis B
description: Hepatitis B is a potentially life-threatening liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is a major global health problem. It can cause both acute (short-term) and chronic (long-term) disease. Chronic hepatitis B increases the risk of developing serious complications like cirrhosis (scarring of the liver), liver failure, and liver cancer. The virus is transmitted through contact with the blood or other body fluids of an infected person.
symptoms: Many people have no symptoms during the acute infection phase.
Symptoms can include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
Jaundice (yellowing of skin and eyes).
Dark urine and pale stools.
Joint pain and fever.
prevention: The Hepatitis B vaccine is safe and highly effective and is the mainstay of prevention.
Practice safe sex by using condoms.
Avoid sharing needles, razors, or toothbrushes.
Ensure that any blood transfusions are screened for HBV.
Use sterile equipment for tattoos and piercings.
treatment: There is no specific treatment for acute hepatitis B; care is supportive.
For chronic hepatitis B, antiviral medications can help suppress the virus and slow the progression of liver damage.
Regular medical monitoring is essential to assess liver health.
In cases of severe liver damage, a liver transplant may be necessary.

name: Hepatitis C
description: Hepatitis C is a viral infection that causes liver inflammation, caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV). For many people, it becomes a chronic infection that can lead to serious, life-threatening health problems like cirrhosis and liver cancer over many years. The virus is primarily spread through contact with contaminated blood, most commonly through the sharing of needles among intravenous drug users. Many people with chronic Hepatitis C are unaware they are infected because they have no symptoms.
symptoms: Most people with acute or chronic hepatitis C have no symptoms.
When symptoms do occur, they are often mild and flu-like, including fatigue, fever, nausea, and muscle aches.
In advanced stages with significant liver damage, symptoms can include jaundice, abdominal fluid buildup (ascites), and easy bruising or bleeding.
prevention: There is currently no vaccine for Hepatitis C.
Prevention focuses on reducing the risk of exposure.
Avoid sharing needles or any drug-injection equipment.
Do not share personal care items that might have come into contact with blood, like razors or glucose monitors.
Use sterile equipment for tattoos and piercings.
Screening of donated blood and organs is a crucial public health measure.
treatment: Hepatitis C is now highly curable with modern treatments.
Direct-acting antiviral (DAA) medications, taken orally for 8-12 weeks, can cure over 95% of people with the infection.
Regular monitoring of liver health is important.
For those with advanced cirrhosis, a liver transplant may be considered.

name: Hernia
description: A hernia occurs when an organ or fatty tissue squeezes through a weak spot in a surrounding muscle or connective tissue called fascia. The most common types of hernias are inguinal (inner groin), femoral (outer groin), umbilical (belly button), and hiatal (upper stomach). They can be caused by a combination of muscle weakness and strain from activities like heavy lifting, persistent coughing, or straining during bowel movements. A hernia can appear as a bulge or lump, which may or may not be painful. Some hernias can lead to life-threatening complications if they become strangulated (blood supply is cut off).
symptoms: A visible lump or bulge in the abdomen or groin that may disappear when lying down.
Aching, pain, or a heavy sensation in the area, especially when lifting, coughing, or straining.
Discomfort or pain that worsens throughout the day.
In hiatal hernias, symptoms can include heartburn, indigestion, and difficulty swallowing.
Nausea and vomiting can be signs of a complicated, obstructed hernia.
prevention: Use proper form when lifting heavy objects.
Maintain a healthy weight to reduce strain on the abdominal wall.
Strengthen core muscles through regular exercise.
Eat a high-fiber diet and drink plenty of water to avoid constipation and straining.
Quit smoking to reduce chronic coughing.
treatment: Watchful waiting may be an option for small, asymptomatic hernias.
Wearing a supportive truss or belt can provide temporary relief.
Surgical repair is the only definitive treatment. This can be done through open surgery or minimally invasive (laparoscopic) surgery, often using a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weak area.
Lifestyle changes to reduce straining.
Pain management for discomfort.

name: Herpangina
description: Herpangina is a common childhood illness caused by enteroviruses, most notably coxsackievirus. It is characterized by the sudden onset of fever and the appearance of small, painful, blister-like sores (ulcers) on the roof of the mouth, throat, and tonsils. Despite its name, it is not related to the herpes virus. It is highly contagious and spreads easily in places like schools and daycare centers. The illness is typically self-limiting and resolves within a week to ten days with supportive care.
symptoms: Sudden onset of high fever
Sore throat and pain upon swallowing
Small grayish bumps or blisters that turn into ulcers, typically on the soft palate, tonsils, and back of the throat
Headache and neck pain
Loss of appetite and drooling in young children
General irritability and fatigue
prevention: Practice good hygiene, including frequent and thorough handwashing.
Clean and disinfect shared toys and surfaces.
Avoid sharing cups, utensils, and close personal contact with someone who is sick.
Keep infected children at home from school or daycare to prevent spreading the virus.
treatment: There is no specific treatment for the virus; care is focused on symptom relief.
Manage fever and pain with over-the-counter medications like acetaminophen or ibuprofen.
Ensure the child stays well-hydrated by offering cool liquids, ice pops, or milk-based drinks.
Avoid acidic or spicy foods that can irritate the mouth sores.
Topical oral anesthetics can provide temporary relief from the pain of mouth sores.

name: Histoplasmosis
description: Histoplasmosis is an infection caused by inhaling the spores of a fungus called *Histoplasma capsulatum*. This fungus is commonly found in soil that contains large amounts of bird or bat droppings. The infection primarily affects the lungs and is often so mild that it produces no apparent symptoms. However, for infants, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems, histoplasmosis can be severe, potentially spreading from the lungs to other parts of the body (disseminated histoplasmosis).
symptoms: Many infections are asymptomatic.
When symptoms occur, they usually appear 3 to 17 days after exposure and can include:
Fever, chills, and headache
A dry cough and chest pain
Muscle aches and fatigue
In chronic or disseminated cases: weight loss, night sweats, and involvement of other organs.
prevention: Avoid disturbing sites that may harbor the fungus, such as chicken coops, caves, or old barns.
Spray contaminated areas with water before cleaning to reduce dust.
Wear a proper respirator mask when working in high-risk environments.
Immunocompromised individuals should be particularly cautious in endemic areas.
treatment: Mild cases of histoplasmosis usually resolve on their own without medication.
For severe, chronic, or disseminated infections, a course of prescription antifungal medication is necessary.
Commonly used drugs include itraconazole for moderate cases and amphotericin B for severe infections.
Treatment can last from several months to a year.

name: HIV/AIDS
description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system, specifically the CD4 cells (T cells). Over time, HIV destroys these cells, making it harder for the body to fight off infections and certain diseases. If left untreated, HIV can progress to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), the most advanced stage of the infection, where the immune system is severely damaged. In India, HIV remains a significant public health challenge. While there is no cure, with access to effective antiretroviral therapy (ART), people with HIV can live long, healthy lives and prevent transmission to others.
symptoms: Acute HIV infection (2-4 weeks after exposure): Flu-like symptoms such as fever, rash, sore throat, and fatigue.
Clinical latency (chronic HIV): Often asymptomatic for many years.
Progression to AIDS: Rapid weight loss, recurring fever or profuse night sweats, extreme fatigue, chronic diarrhea, and frequent opportunistic infections.
prevention: Practice safe sex by using condoms correctly and consistently.
Never share needles or other injection equipment.
Get tested for HIV and other STIs regularly.
Use pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) if at high risk.
Prevent mother-to-child transmission through ART during pregnancy.
treatment: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the standard treatment, involving a combination of HIV medicines taken daily.
ART cannot cure HIV but can dramatically prolong lives and reduce the risk of transmission to others by lowering the viral load to undetectable levels.
Supportive care to manage opportunistic infections and other health complications.
Maintaining a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise is also important.

name: Hookworm Infection
description: A hookworm infection is an intestinal parasitic disease caused by two main species of roundworms, *Ancylostoma duodenale* and *Necator americanus*. The infection is contracted when hookworm larvae in soil contaminated by feces penetrate the skin, usually through bare feet. The larvae then travel through the bloodstream to the lungs, are coughed up, swallowed, and finally mature in the small intestine. There, they attach to the intestinal wall and feed on blood, which can lead to significant iron-deficiency anemia, malnutrition, and developmental delays, especially in children and pregnant women.
symptoms: An itchy, red rash at the site where the larvae entered the skin (ground itch).
Abdominal pain, diarrhea, and loss of appetite.
Iron-deficiency anemia, leading to fatigue, weakness, and pale skin.
In children, chronic infection can lead to poor growth and impaired cognitive development.
Most light infections are asymptomatic.
prevention: Always wear shoes when walking on potentially contaminated soil.
Improve sanitation by using toilets and preventing open defecation.
Practice good personal hygiene, including handwashing.
Treat infected individuals to reduce soil contamination.
Periodic deworming programs in endemic communities.
treatment: Anthelmintic (anti-worm) medications, such as albendazole or mebendazole, are effective at killing the adult worms.
Iron supplements are often prescribed to treat the associated anemia.
Nutritional therapy and support to address malnutrition.

name: Hypertension
description: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a common and serious medical condition in which the long-term force of the blood against your artery walls is high enough that it may eventually cause health problems, such as heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure. Blood pressure is determined both by the amount of blood your heart pumps and the amount of resistance to blood flow in your arteries. It is often called the 'silent killer' because it can exist for years without any symptoms, while silently damaging the cardiovascular system.
symptoms: Hypertension is largely asymptomatic.
In cases of very high blood pressure (hypertensive crisis), some people may experience:
Severe headaches
Shortness of breath
Nosebleeds
Dizziness or vision problems
prevention: Get your blood pressure checked regularly.
Eat a heart-healthy diet that is low in salt (sodium) and rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
Engage in regular physical activity.
Maintain a healthy weight.
Limit alcohol consumption and avoid smoking.
treatment: Lifestyle modifications are the first line of defense.
Antihypertensive medications, such as diuretics, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, or calcium channel blockers, are often necessary.
Treatment is typically lifelong.
Regular follow-up with a healthcare provider to monitor blood pressure and adjust treatment as needed.

name: Hyperthyroidism
description: Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces and releases an excessive amount of thyroid hormones. These hormones control the body's metabolism, so an overproduction can significantly speed up many of the body's functions. The most common cause is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder. Other causes include thyroid nodules or thyroiditis (inflammation of the thyroid). If left untreated, hyperthyroidism can lead to serious heart problems, bone loss (osteoporosis), and a dangerous condition called thyroid storm.
symptoms: Unintentional weight loss, despite an increased appetite
Rapid or irregular heartbeat (palpitations)
Nervousness, anxiety, and irritability
Increased sensitivity to heat and excessive sweating
Tremors, usually a fine trembling in the hands and fingers
Fatigue, muscle weakness, and difficulty sleeping
Enlargement of the thyroid gland (goiter)
prevention: Most causes of hyperthyroidism cannot be prevented.
Regular health checkups can help with early detection.
Maintain a balanced diet and avoid excessive intake of iodine-rich foods or supplements unless advised by a doctor.
Managing autoimmune conditions and stress may be beneficial.
treatment: Anti-thyroid medications to block the production of thyroid hormones.
Radioactive iodine therapy to permanently shrink or destroy the thyroid gland.
Beta-blocker medications to control symptoms like rapid heart rate and tremors.
Surgical removal of all or part of the thyroid gland (thyroidectomy).

name: Hypothyroidism
description: Hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) is a common disorder where the thyroid gland does not produce enough crucial thyroid hormones. Since these hormones regulate the body's metabolism, a deficiency can cause many of the body's functions to slow down. The most common cause is Hashimoto's disease, an autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the thyroid. Other causes include iodine deficiency, thyroid surgery, or radiation therapy. It is more common in women, especially those over 60, and requires lifelong management.
symptoms: Persistent fatigue and lethargy
Unexplained weight gain or difficulty losing weight
Dry skin and thinning hair
Increased sensitivity to cold
Constipation
Muscle aches, weakness, and joint stiffness
Depression and impaired memory ('brain fog')
prevention: Most causes of hypothyroidism cannot be prevented.
Ensure an adequate intake of iodine through iodized salt and a balanced diet.
Regular health screenings can detect the condition early, especially for those with a family history or other autoimmune diseases.
Healthy lifestyle choices support overall endocrine health.
treatment: The standard treatment is lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
Daily use of the synthetic thyroid hormone levothyroxine restores adequate hormone levels, reversing the signs and symptoms.
Regular blood tests are required to monitor hormone levels and ensure the correct medication dosage.
Consistent lifestyle changes, including a healthy diet, can support treatment.

name: Impetigo
description: Impetigo is a common and highly contagious superficial bacterial skin infection that primarily affects infants and young children. It is usually caused by *Staphylococcus aureus* or *Streptococcus pyogenes* bacteria. The infection often begins in minor cuts, insect bites, or areas of eczema, but can also develop on healthy skin. It typically appears as red sores or blisters that rupture, ooze for a few days, and then form a characteristic yellowish-brown or 'honey-colored' crust. Good hygiene is essential to prevent its spread.
symptoms: Red sores that quickly rupture, ooze fluid, and then form a honey-colored crust.
Sores most commonly appear around the nose and mouth but can spread to other areas.
A more serious form, bullous impetigo, causes larger, painless, fluid-filled blisters.
Itching and soreness at the site of the sores.
Swollen lymph nodes may occur in some cases.
prevention: Practice good hygiene, including regular and thorough handwashing with soap and water.
Keep skin clean and dry.
Clean and cover any cuts, scrapes, or insect bites promptly.
Avoid sharing personal items like towels, clothing, and bedding with someone who has impetigo.
Keep the fingernails of infected children short to prevent scratching.
treatment: For mild cases, a topical antibiotic ointment or cream is usually sufficient.
For more widespread or severe infections, oral antibiotics will be prescribed.
Gently washing the sores with soap and water to remove the crusts can help the antibiotic ointment work more effectively.
It's important to keep the sores covered to prevent spreading the infection to others.

name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
description: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) is a broad term that describes conditions with chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. The two most common types are Ulcerative Colitis, which causes long-lasting inflammation and sores (ulcers) in the innermost lining of the colon and rectum, and Crohn's Disease, which can affect any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus and often involves deeper layers of the bowel wall. IBD is an autoimmune condition that can be debilitating and may lead to life-threatening complications if not managed properly.
symptoms: Persistent diarrhea, which may contain blood, pus, or mucus
Abdominal pain, cramping, and bloating
Rectal bleeding
Urgency to have a bowel movement
