Topical or oral antibiotics to control bacterial infection.
Surgical treatments for advanced periodontitis, such as flap surgery, bone grafting, or guided tissue regeneration.

name: Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD)
description: Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD) is a common circulatory problem in which narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs, most often the legs. It is typically caused by atherosclerosis, the same process of plaque buildup that causes coronary artery disease. When your limbs don't receive enough blood flow to keep up with demand, it can cause symptoms like leg pain when walking (claudication). PAD is also a sign of widespread atherosclerosis, meaning individuals with PAD have a significantly increased risk of heart attack and stroke.
symptoms: Painful cramping in the hip, thigh, or calf muscles after activity, which resolves with rest (intermittent claudication).
Leg numbness or weakness.
Coldness in the lower leg or foot, especially when compared with the other side.
Sores on the toes, feet, or legs that won't heal.
A change in the color of the legs or shiny skin on the legs.
Hair loss or slower hair growth on the feet and legs.
prevention: Quitting smoking is the single most important step.
Effectively manage diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol.
Maintain a healthy weight.
Engage in regular physical exercise; a supervised exercise program is often recommended.
Eat a diet low in saturated and trans fats.
treatment: Aggressive lifestyle changes (smoking cessation, diet, exercise).
Medications to lower cholesterol (statins), control blood pressure, and prevent blood clots (antiplatelet drugs like aspirin or clopidogrel).
Medications specifically to improve walking distance.
In more severe cases, minimally invasive procedures like angioplasty and stenting or surgical procedures like bypass surgery may be used to restore blood flow.

name: Plantar Fasciitis
description: Plantar fasciitis is one of the most common causes of heel pain. It involves inflammation of the plantar fascia, a thick, web-like band of tissue that runs across the bottom of your foot and connects your heel bone to your toes. It acts as a shock absorber, supporting the arch of your foot. Strain and tension on this ligament can cause tiny tears, leading to inflammation and pain. The pain is typically a stabbing pain near the heel that is often worst with the first steps in the morning.
symptoms: Stabbing pain in the bottom of the heel.
Pain that is usually most severe with the first few steps after waking up or after long periods of rest.
Pain that is often worse after exercise, not during it.
Stiffness and pain in the heel after prolonged standing.
Swelling or tenderness in the heel.
prevention: Wear shoes with good arch support and cushioning.
Maintain a healthy weight to reduce stress on your feet.
Regularly stretch your calves, Achilles tendon, and the bottom of your foot.
Avoid walking barefoot on hard surfaces.
Vary your exercise routine to avoid overuse injuries.
treatment: Conservative treatments are effective for most people.
Rest, ice, and over-the-counter pain relievers (NSAIDs).
Physical therapy and specific stretching exercises.
Using night splints that stretch your calf and the arch of your foot while you sleep.
Orthotics or supportive shoe inserts.
In persistent cases, treatments may include corticosteroid injections, shock wave therapy, or surgery.

name: Pneumococcal Disease
description: Pneumococcal disease is a name for any infection caused by bacteria called *Streptococcus pneumoniae* (pneumococcus). These bacteria can cause many types of illnesses, ranging from mild ear and sinus infections to severe, life-threatening conditions like pneumonia (lung infection), meningitis (infection of the lining of the brain and spinal cord), and bacteremia (bloodstream infection). The disease is most dangerous for young children, older adults, and individuals with weakened immune systems or certain chronic health conditions. It spreads through respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing.
symptoms: Symptoms vary depending on the part of the body infected.
Pneumonia: Fever, cough, chest pain, and difficulty breathing.
Meningitis: Fever, headache, stiff neck, and sensitivity to light.
Bacteremia/Sepsis: Fever, chills, and low alertness.
Otitis Media (Ear Infection): Ear pain, fever, and irritability.
prevention: Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent pneumococcal disease.
There are two types of vaccines (PCV13, PCV15, PCV20, and PPSV23) recommended for different age groups and risk categories.
Practice good hand hygiene.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Do not smoke.
treatment: Pneumococcal infections are treated with antibiotics.
However, some strains of the bacteria have become resistant to certain antibiotics, making prevention through vaccination even more important.
Hospitalization and supportive care, such as oxygen therapy, may be needed for severe infections like pneumonia or meningitis.

name: Pneumonia
description: Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung affecting primarily the microscopic air sacs known as alveoli. It is typically caused by infection with viruses, bacteria (like Streptococcus pneumoniae), or fungi. The inflammation causes the alveoli to fill with fluid or pus, making it difficult to breathe and limiting oxygen intake. It can range in seriousness from mild to life-threatening and is particularly dangerous for infants, older adults, and people with weakened immune systems. In India, it remains a significant cause of mortality in children under five.
symptoms: Cough, which may produce greenish, yellow, or even bloody mucus (phlegm)
Fever, sweating, and shaking chills
Shortness of breath or rapid, shallow breathing
Sharp or stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breathing or coughing
Loss of appetite, low energy, and fatigue
Nausea and vomiting, especially in young children
Confusion or changes in mental awareness, particularly in older adults
prevention: Vaccination (Pneumococcal vaccine, flu shot, Hib vaccine)
Practice good hygiene: Wash hands frequently and thoroughly
Don't smoke, as smoking damages your lungs' natural defenses
Maintain a strong immune system through a healthy diet, regular exercise, and adequate sleep
Manage chronic conditions like asthma, diabetes, or heart disease
treatment: Antibiotics for bacterial pneumonia (complete the full course)
Antiviral medications for viral pneumonia (e.g., influenza-related)
Fever reducers/pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen
Cough medicine to calm your cough for rest (use with caution)
Oxygen therapy to maintain blood oxygen levels
Intravenous (IV) fluids and respiratory therapy in severe cases
Ample rest and fluid intake to help the body recover

name: Polio
description: Polio (poliomyelitis) is a highly contagious viral disease that largely affects children under 5 years of age. The virus is transmitted through contaminated water or food or contact with an infected person. It invades the nervous system and can cause irreversible paralysis in a matter of hours. While most infections are asymptomatic, a small percentage can be devastating. Thanks to global vaccination efforts, polio is now eradicated in most parts of the world, including India.
symptoms: Most infections (over 70%) show no symptoms
Fever and fatigue
Headache and vomiting
Stiffness in the neck and pain in the limbs
Sore throat
Muscle weakness or tenderness
Paralysis or loss of reflexes (in severe cases)
prevention: Vaccination with Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) or Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine (IPV) is the most effective method
Maintaining high levels of hygiene and sanitation
Ensuring access to clean drinking water
Global surveillance to detect and respond to any outbreaks
treatment: There is no cure for polio; treatment focuses on managing symptoms
Supportive care, including bed rest and monitoring
Pain relievers for muscle aches
Physical therapy and assistive devices (braces, wheelchairs) to improve mobility in cases of paralysis
Ventilators to assist with breathing if respiratory muscles are affected

name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
description: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is a common hormonal disorder among women of reproductive age. The exact cause is unknown but involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors. It is characterized by high levels of androgens (male hormones), which can disrupt the menstrual cycle and cause numerous small cysts on the ovaries. It is a leading cause of infertility and can increase the long-term risk of developing type 2 diabetes and heart disease.
symptoms: Irregular, infrequent, or prolonged menstrual periods
Unexplained weight gain, especially around the abdomen
Acne, oily skin, and dandruff
Excess hair growth (hirsutism) on the face, chest, back, or buttocks
Thinning hair or male-pattern baldness
Darkened skin patches (acanthosis nigricans), especially in body folds
Pelvic pain
prevention: While PCOS cannot be prevented, its complications can be managed
Maintain a healthy weight through a balanced diet and regular physical activity
Monitor and control blood sugar levels
Regular medical check-ups to manage hormonal imbalances
Limit consumption of processed foods and sugars
treatment: Lifestyle changes: diet and exercise are first-line treatments
Hormonal therapy, such as birth control pills, to regulate periods and reduce androgen levels
Metformin to improve insulin resistance and manage blood sugar
Fertility treatments like Clomiphene to stimulate ovulation if pregnancy is desired
Anti-androgen medications to reduce excess hair growth and acne

name: Prostatitis
description: Prostatitis is the inflammation and swelling of the prostate gland, a small gland located below the bladder in men that produces seminal fluid. It can be acute or chronic and may be caused by a bacterial infection or by inflammation without a clear cause (nonbacterial prostatitis). It affects men of all ages but is more common in those under 50. It can cause significant pain and urinary issues, impacting quality of life.
symptoms: Pain or burning sensation during urination (dysuria)
Difficulty urinating, such as dribbling or hesitant urination
Frequent or urgent need to urinate, especially at night (nocturia)
Cloudy or bloody urine
Pain in the abdomen, groin, lower back, or perineum (area between scrotum and rectum)
Painful ejaculation or sexual dysfunction
Flu-like symptoms (in acute bacterial prostatitis)
prevention: Practice good hygiene to prevent bacterial entry into the urethra
Stay well-hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids
Manage stress, as it can worsen symptoms of chronic prostatitis
Avoid activities that irritate the prostate, like prolonged sitting or cycling
Practice safe sex to reduce the risk of STIs that can cause prostatitis
treatment: A course of antibiotics (often for several weeks) for bacterial prostatitis
Anti-inflammatory agents like NSAIDs to reduce pain and swelling
Alpha-blockers to relax bladder and prostate muscles, improving urine flow
Lifestyle changes, such as avoiding alcohol, caffeine, and spicy foods
Pelvic floor physical therapy and warm baths (sitz baths) to relieve discomfort

name: Psoriasis
description: Psoriasis is a chronic, non-contagious autoimmune condition that accelerates the life cycle of skin cells. This causes cells to build up rapidly on the surface of the skin, forming scales and red patches that are sometimes itchy and painful. The condition is driven by an overactive immune system and has genetic links. Flares can be triggered by stress, infection, or certain medications. In India, social stigma can be a significant challenge for patients.
symptoms: Red, raised, inflamed patches of skin (plaques)
Silvery-white scales or plaques on the red patches
Dry skin that may crack and bleed
Itching, burning, or soreness around patches
Thickened, pitted, or ridged nails
Swollen and stiff joints (in psoriatic arthritis)
prevention: While the disease itself cannot be prevented, flare-ups can be minimized
Avoid triggers like stress, smoking, and excessive alcohol consumption
Protect skin from injury (cuts, scrapes) and sunburn
Moisturize regularly to keep skin hydrated
Maintain a healthy diet and weight
Consult a doctor before taking medications known to trigger psoriasis
treatment: Topical treatments: Corticosteroid creams, vitamin D analogues, and retinoids
Phototherapy (light therapy): Controlled exposure to natural or artificial ultraviolet light
Oral or injected medications: Methotrexate, cyclosporine, or biologics for severe cases
Moisturizers and emollients to soothe dry skin
Lifestyle modifications to manage triggers and symptoms

name: Psoriatic Arthritis
description: Psoriatic arthritis is a form of inflammatory arthritis that affects some people who have psoriasis. It is an autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks healthy cells and tissues, causing inflammation in the joints and an overproduction of skin cells. It can affect any part of the body, including fingertips and the spine, and can range from mild to severe. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent permanent joint damage.
symptoms: Pain, stiffness, and swelling in one or more joints
Morning stiffness that improves with activity
Red, scaly skin patches (psoriasis plaques)
Nail changes, such as pitting, crumbling, or separation from the nail bed
Swelling of an entire finger or toe (dactylitis or 'sausage digit')
Pain in the feet, especially at the back of the heel (Achilles tendinitis) or sole (plantar fasciitis)
Fatigue and eye inflammation (uveitis)
prevention: There is no known way to prevent psoriatic arthritis
Early management of psoriasis may help
Maintain a healthy weight to reduce stress on joints
Avoid smoking, as it is a risk factor
Manage stress, as it can trigger flare-ups
Regular, low-impact exercise to maintain joint flexibility
treatment: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to reduce pain and inflammation
Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) like methotrexate to slow disease progression
Biologic agents that target specific parts of the immune system
Steroid injections into affected joints for rapid relief
Physical and occupational therapy to protect joints and improve function
Surgery, such as joint replacement, for severely damaged joints

name: Pulmonary Fibrosis
description: Pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive and chronic lung disease characterized by the scarring (fibrosis) of lung tissue. This scarring makes the lung tissue thick and stiff, reducing the lungs' ability to transfer oxygen into the bloodstream. The cause is often unknown (idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), but it can also be triggered by exposure to toxins, certain medical conditions, or radiation therapy. The disease course varies, but it generally worsens over time.
symptoms: Progressive shortness of breath (dyspnea), especially with exertion
A dry, hacking chronic cough that doesn't go away
Persistent fatigue and weakness
Aching muscles and joints
Widening and rounding of the tips of the fingers or toes (clubbing)
Unexplained weight loss
prevention: Prevention is difficult as the cause is often unknown
Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke
Wear appropriate protective equipment (masks, respirators) in occupations with exposure to lung toxins like silica, asbestos, or dust
Regular lung checkups, especially with a family history of the disease
Get vaccinated against flu and pneumonia to prevent respiratory infections
treatment: There is no cure; treatment aims to slow progression and manage symptoms
Anti-fibrotic drugs like pirfenidone and nintedanib to slow the rate of scarring
Oxygen therapy to improve breathing and reduce shortness of breath
Pulmonary rehabilitation to improve daily functioning and quality of life
Cough suppressants and other medications to manage symptoms
A lung transplant may be an option in severe, advanced cases

name: Rabies
description: Rabies is a deadly viral disease that affects the central nervous system of mammals, including humans. It is transmitted through the saliva of an infected animal, typically through a bite or scratch. The virus travels from the wound to the brain, where it causes severe inflammation. Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is nearly always fatal. However, it is 100% preventable with prompt and appropriate medical care after exposure.
symptoms: Initial symptoms are flu-like: fever, headache, and general weakness
Discomfort, pricking, or itching sensation at the site of the bite
Progression to cerebral dysfunction: anxiety, confusion, agitation
Hydrophobia (fear of water) due to difficulty in swallowing
Aerophobia (fear of drafts or fresh air)
Hallucinations, delirium, insomnia
Paralysis, coma, and ultimately death
prevention: Vaccination of domestic pets like dogs and cats
Avoiding contact with stray and wild animals
Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP): a course of rabies vaccine and, in some cases, rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) administered immediately after exposure
Educating communities about animal bite prevention and management
treatment: There is no effective treatment for rabies once clinical symptoms begin
Immediate and thorough cleaning of the wound with soap and water for at least 15 minutes is crucial
Urgent administration of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), including the rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin
Supportive care in an intensive care unit for symptomatic patients, though survival is extremely rare

name: Relapsing Fever
description: Relapsing fever is an infectious disease caused by several species of bacteria from the genus Borrelia. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected ticks (tick-borne relapsing fever) or lice (louse-borne relapsing fever). The disease is named for its characteristic pattern of recurring episodes of fever, each lasting several days, separated by periods of feeling well. Louse-borne relapsing fever is more severe and can cause large epidemics.
symptoms: Sudden onset of high fever, often exceeding 103°F (39°C)
Severe headache, muscle aches (myalgia), and joint pain (arthralgia)
Chills and shaking
Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain
A rash may appear on the trunk and limbs
Confusion, dizziness, or photophobia (sensitivity to light)
Fever episodes end abruptly (crisis) and return after about a week
prevention: Avoid tick and lice exposure, especially in endemic areas
Use insect repellents containing DEET on skin and permethrin on clothing
Wear protective clothing, such as long sleeves and pants, when in wooded or grassy areas
Maintain good personal hygiene to prevent louse infestations
Check for and promptly remove ticks from your body and pets
treatment: Treatment with antibiotics, such as doxycycline or tetracycline, is highly effective
A Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (a sudden worsening of symptoms) can occur after the first dose of antibiotics, requiring medical monitoring
Supportive care including hydration with intravenous fluids
Pain relievers and fever reducers to manage symptoms

name: Restless Legs Syndrome
description: Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS), also known as Willis-Ekbom disease, is a neurological sensory disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move one's legs. This urge is often accompanied by uncomfortable sensations described as creeping, crawling, or pulling. Symptoms typically occur during periods of rest or inactivity, such as sitting or lying down, and are more severe in the evening and at night. It can significantly disrupt sleep and reduce quality of life.
symptoms: An overwhelming urge to move the legs, often irresistible
Unpleasant sensations in the legs (creeping, itching, pulling, aching)
Symptoms begin or worsen during periods of rest or inactivity
Relief from the urge is found through movement like stretching or walking
Symptoms are worse in the evening or at night
Involuntary leg twitching or jerking during sleep (periodic limb movement of sleep)
Chronic sleep disturbance leading to daytime fatigue
prevention: The exact cause is often unknown, so prevention is not always possible
Maintain adequate levels of iron, magnesium, and folate through diet or supplements
Avoid triggers like caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine, especially in the evening
Engage in regular, moderate exercise
Establish a regular sleep schedule and practice good sleep hygiene
Manage underlying conditions like kidney failure or diabetes
treatment: Lifestyle changes: leg massages, warm baths, and relaxation exercises
Iron supplements if an iron deficiency is identified
Medications that increase dopamine in the brain (dopamine agonists)
Drugs affecting calcium channels, opioids, and muscle relaxants may also be prescribed
A vibrating pad or foot wrap that applies pressure to the feet

name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
description: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, primarily the synovium (the lining of the membranes that surround the joints). This leads to inflammation, causing painful swelling, and can eventually result in bone erosion and joint deformity. RA can also affect other parts of the body, such as the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels. It is more common in women and typically starts in middle age.
symptoms: Tender, warm, and swollen joints, often affecting smaller joints first (wrists, hands, feet)
Symmetrical joint involvement (affecting both sides of the body)
Joint stiffness that is usually worse in the mornings and after periods of inactivity
Persistent fatigue, fever, and loss of appetite
Firm bumps of tissue under the skin on the arms (rheumatoid nodules)
Weight loss
prevention: There is no known way to prevent RA
Managing risk factors: Quitting smoking is highly recommended as it's a strong risk factor
Maintaining a healthy weight to reduce stress on joints
A diet rich in anti-inflammatory foods like omega-3 fatty acids may be beneficial
Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent or slow joint damage
treatment: Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to slow the disease's progression and save joints from permanent damage
Biologic agents, a newer class of DMARDs, that target specific parts of the immune system
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and corticosteroids to reduce pain and inflammation
Physical and occupational therapy to learn exercises that keep joints flexible
Surgery, including joint repair or replacement, in cases of severe joint damage

name: Ringworm
description: Ringworm, or tinea, is a common fungal infection of the skin, hair, or nails. Despite its name, it is not caused by a worm but by a type of fungus called a dermatophyte. The infection is characterized by a circular, itchy, red rash with clearer skin in the middle, resembling a ring. It is contagious and can spread through direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person or animal, or by touching contaminated objects like towels or sports equipment. India's warm, humid climate provides an ideal environment for the fungus to thrive.
symptoms: A red, scaly, or cracked circular rash
Itching and a burning sensation in the affected area
Clear or scaly area inside the ring, sometimes with bumps
Hair loss in the affected area (if on the scalp or beard)
Thick, discolored, or brittle nails (if the nails are infected)
prevention: Practice good personal hygiene; wash hands regularly
Keep skin clean and dry, especially after sweating
Avoid sharing personal items like towels, clothing, combs, or sports gear
Wear breathable clothing and change socks and underwear daily
Avoid walking barefoot in public areas like locker rooms and showers
Treat infected pets as they can transmit the fungus to humans
treatment: Over-the-counter (OTC) antifungal creams, lotions, or powders containing clotrimazole or miconazole
Prescription-strength topical antifungal medications
Oral antifungal medication for severe or widespread infections, or infections of the scalp or nails
Keep the affected area clean and dry during treatment

name: Roseola
description: Roseola (also known as sixth disease or exanthem subitum) is a common and generally mild viral illness that typically affects children between 6 months and 2 years of age. It is caused by two strains of human herpesvirus. The illness characteristically starts with a sudden, high fever that can last for several days, which is then followed by a distinctive rash once the fever breaks. It is contagious but usually resolves without complications.
symptoms: Sudden high fever (often over 103°F or 39.4°C) lasting 3 to 5 days
After the fever subsides, a pinkish-red rash appears, typically starting on the trunk and spreading to the neck, face, arms, and legs
Irritability and fussiness in infants
Mild diarrhea or decreased appetite
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
A mild sore throat or runny nose
prevention: There is no vaccine to prevent roseola
Practice good hygiene, such as frequent handwashing, to prevent the spread of the virus
Avoid sharing cups and utensils
Keep infected children at home and away from others until the fever has been gone for at least 24 hours to prevent transmission
treatment: Treatment is primarily supportive and focuses on comfort
Manage fever with over-the-counter medications like acetaminophen or ibuprofen (do not give aspirin to children)
Ensure the child drinks plenty of fluids to stay hydrated
Encourage rest
The rash does not require treatment and will fade on its own within a few days

name: Rotavirus Infection
description: Rotavirus is a highly contagious virus that is the leading cause of severe dehydrating gastroenteritis (inflammation of the stomach and intestines) among infants and young children worldwide. The virus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route. Before the development of a vaccine, nearly every child was infected with the virus by age 5. While infections in adults are usually mild, in children they can lead to severe diarrhea, vomiting, fever, and dehydration, which can be life-threatening without prompt treatment.
symptoms: Severe watery diarrhea
Frequent vomiting
Fever and abdominal pain
Loss of appetite
Signs of dehydration: decreased urination, dry mouth and throat, feeling dizzy when standing up, crying with few or no tears
prevention: The rotavirus vaccine is the best way to protect children from the disease. It is given in multiple doses starting at a young age
Frequent and thorough handwashing with soap and water, especially after using the toilet or changing diapers
Maintaining good hygiene and sanitation practices
Cleaning and disinfecting contaminated surfaces
treatment: There is no specific medicine to treat rotavirus infection; antibiotics are not effective
The primary focus of treatment is to prevent dehydration
Oral rehydration solutions (ORS) to replace lost fluids and electrolytes
Continue feeding (breast milk, formula, or food) as tolerated
In severe cases, intravenous (IV) fluids may be required in a hospital setting
Antidiarrheal medicines are not recommended for children

name: Sarcoidosis
description: Sarcoidosis is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of tiny collections of inflammatory cells called granulomas in different parts of the body. The cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be an exaggerated immune response to an unknown substance. It most commonly affects the lungs and lymph nodes, but it can also affect the skin, eyes, heart, and other organs. The disease course is variable; it may resolve on its own or become a chronic condition requiring long-term management.
symptoms: General symptoms: Fatigue, fever, swollen lymph nodes, and weight loss
Lung symptoms: Persistent dry cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain
Skin symptoms: Rashes, sores, or reddish-purple bumps (erythema nodosum), often on the shins
Eye symptoms: Blurred vision, eye pain, severe redness, and sensitivity to light
Joint pain and swelling
prevention: There is no known way to prevent sarcoidosis as its cause is unknown
Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise
Avoid exposure to environmental triggers or toxins that may cause inflammation
Do not smoke
Regular health screenings to monitor organ function if diagnosed
treatment: Many patients do not require treatment as the disease may resolve spontaneously
Corticosteroids, like prednisone, are the primary treatment to reduce inflammation
Immunosuppressive drugs, such as methotrexate or azathioprine, for patients who don't respond to corticosteroids
Biologic medications like infliximab for severe cases
Symptom management for fatigue, pain, and organ-specific issues

name: Scabies
description: Scabies is a highly contagious skin infestation caused by a tiny, eight-legged burrowing mite called Sarcoptes scabiei. The mites burrow into the upper layer of the skin where they live and lay their eggs, triggering an allergic reaction that causes intense itching and a pimple-like rash. It spreads rapidly through prolonged, direct skin-to-skin contact, making it common in crowded conditions like schools, nursing homes, and households. In India, it's prevalent in areas with limited access to clean water and sanitation.
symptoms: Intense itching, especially at night
A pimple-like rash, tiny blisters, or scales
Burrow tracks: tiny, raised, and crooked grayish-white or skin-colored lines on the skin surface
Sores caused by scratching, which can become infected
Common sites include the webbing between fingers, wrists, elbows, armpits, and groin
prevention: Avoid direct skin-to-skin contact with an infected person
Do not share clothing, towels, or bedding used by someone with scabies
All household members and close contacts of an infected person should be treated at the same time, even if they don't have symptoms
Machine wash and dry all bedding, clothing, and towels used within the last three days on high heat
treatment: Prescription medicated creams or lotions (scabicides), such as permethrin cream, which are applied to the entire body from the neck down
Oral medication, like ivermectin, for severe or crusted scabies or for outbreaks in institutions
Antihistamines and steroid creams to relieve itching and inflammation
Antibiotics if a secondary bacterial infection develops from scratching

name: Scarlet Fever
description: Scarlet fever is a bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. It is caused by Group A Streptococcus bacteria, which produce a toxin that causes a distinctive rash. It is characterized by a bright red rash that covers most of the body, a sore throat, and a high fever. Scarlet fever is most common in children between the ages of 5 and 15. It is important to treat it with antibiotics to prevent rare but serious long-term complications like rheumatic fever or kidney disease.
symptoms: A red rash that feels like sandpaper and looks like a sunburn, typically starting on the neck and chest and spreading
A very red, sore throat
High fever (101°F or higher)
A flushed face with a pale ring around the mouth
Strawberry tongue: A white coating on the tongue early on, which then peels to reveal a red and bumpy surface
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
prevention: There is no vaccine for scarlet fever
Practice good hygiene: wash hands frequently with soap and water
Avoid sharing eating utensils, cups, towels, or other personal items
Cover your mouth and nose when you cough or sneeze
Prompt antibiotic treatment for strep throat can prevent the development of scarlet fever
treatment: A full course of antibiotics, such as penicillin or amoxicillin, is essential to kill the bacteria
Pain relievers and fever reducers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen
Gargling with salt water and drinking plenty of fluids to soothe the sore throat
Rest to help the body fight the infection
Completing the entire antibiotic course is crucial even if symptoms improve, to prevent complications

name: Sciatica
description: Sciatica is not a disease itself, but rather a symptom of an underlying medical problem. It refers to pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which branches from the lower back through the hips and buttocks and down each leg. It most commonly occurs when a herniated disk, bone spur on the spine, or narrowing of the spine (spinal stenosis) compresses part of the nerve. This causes inflammation, pain, and often some numbness in the affected leg. The pain can range from a mild ache to a sharp, burning sensation or excruciating pain.
symptoms: Pain that radiates from the lower back (lumbar) to the buttock and down the back of the leg
The pain is typically felt on only one side of the body
A sensation of numbness, tingling, or 'pins and needles' in the leg or foot
Muscle weakness in the affected leg or foot
Pain can be sharp, burning, or feel like a jolt or electric shock
Pain may worsen with prolonged sitting, standing, sneezing, or coughing
prevention: Engage in regular exercise to strengthen the core and back muscles
Maintain proper posture when sitting and standing to reduce pressure on the lower back
Use good body mechanics when lifting heavy objects; lift with your legs, not your back
Maintain a healthy weight to minimize stress on the spine
Avoid prolonged sitting and take regular breaks to stretch
treatment: Conservative treatments are often effective: hot or cold packs, stretching, and over-the-counter pain relievers (NSAIDs)
Physical therapy to improve posture, strengthen back muscles, and increase flexibility
Prescription medications, including muscle relaxants or anti-inflammatories
Epidural steroid injections to reduce inflammation around the nerve
Surgery is reserved for severe cases where pain persists or there is significant leg weakness

name: Scrub Typhus
description: Scrub typhus is an acute, febrile infectious disease caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected larval mites (chiggers), which are commonly found in areas with heavy scrub vegetation. The disease is endemic in parts of Asia, Australia, and the Pacific Islands. If left untreated, scrub typhus can lead to severe organ complications and can be fatal.
symptoms: Sudden onset of fever and chills
Severe headache and body aches
A distinctive dark, scab-like lesion called an 'eschar' at the site of the chigger bite
A macular rash that appears on the trunk and spreads to the limbs
Enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy)
In severe cases: mental changes, confusion, pneumonia, or organ failure
prevention: Avoid areas with heavy vegetation and scrub where mites may be present
Use insect repellents containing DEET on exposed skin
Wear protective clothing, such as long sleeves, long pants, and boots
Treat clothing and gear with permethrin
Inspect your body for mites after returning from potential exposure areas
treatment: Prompt treatment with the antibiotic doxycycline is highly effective and considered the drug of choice
Azithromycin is an alternative for children and pregnant women
Supportive therapy to manage fever and pain
Hospitalization may be required for severe cases with complications

name: Scurvy
description: Scurvy is a disease caused by a severe and chronic deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid). Vitamin C is crucial for the synthesis of collagen, an essential protein for forming and maintaining connective tissues, including skin, blood vessels, cartilage, and bones. Without it, the body cannot properly repair itself, leading to a breakdown of tissues. While rare in modern times, it can affect people with poor diets, alcohol use disorder, or certain medical conditions that affect nutrient absorption.
symptoms: Initial symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, irritability, and aching limbs
Swollen, spongy, and bleeding gums, which can lead to tooth loss
Easy bruising and small, pinpoint bleeding spots under the skin (petechiae)
Poor wound healing and reopening of old scars
Joint pain, especially in the legs
Dry, scaly skin and coiled body hair
Anemia
prevention: Consume a balanced diet rich in vitamin C
Excellent sources include citrus fruits (oranges, lemons), berries, kiwis, bell peppers, broccoli, tomatoes, and leafy green vegetables
Avoid overcooking vegetables, as heat can destroy vitamin C
Take vitamin C supplements if dietary intake is insufficient
treatment: Treatment involves replacing the vitamin C that is missing from the body
Administering high doses of vitamin C supplements, either orally or via injection in severe cases
Increasing the dietary intake of vitamin C-rich foods
Symptoms like pain and weakness often improve within days, while others like bleeding gums may take a few weeks to resolve

name: Sepsis
description: Sepsis is a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. When the body's immune system, which normally fights infection, overreacts, it releases a cascade of chemicals into the bloodstream that cause widespread inflammation. This inflammation can lead to blood clots, leaky blood vessels, and ultimately, impaired blood flow. This deprives organs of nutrients and oxygen and can lead to organ damage, organ failure (septic shock), and death. Sepsis is a medical emergency that requires rapid diagnosis and treatment.
symptoms: A change in mental status, such as confusion or disorientation
High heart rate (tachycardia) or low blood pressure (hypotension)
Fever, shivering, or feeling very cold
Shortness of breath or rapid breathing
Extreme pain or discomfort, often described as 'the worst ever'
Clammy or sweaty skin
prevention: Prevent infections by getting vaccinated against flu, pneumonia, and other infections
Practice good hygiene, including thorough handwashing
Clean scrapes and wounds properly
Seek prompt medical care for any infection and manage chronic medical conditions effectively
Know the symptoms of sepsis and seek immediate medical attention if they occur
treatment: Sepsis is a medical emergency requiring hospitalization
Rapid administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics to fight the underlying infection
Intravenous (IV) fluids to maintain blood pressure and organ perfusion
Vasopressors (medications to raise blood pressure) if fluids are not sufficient
Oxygen therapy or mechanical ventilation to support breathing
Supportive care for organ failure, such as dialysis for kidney failure

name: Shingles (Herpes Zoster)
description: Shingles, also known as herpes zoster, is a viral infection that causes a painful skin rash. It is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, the same virus that causes chickenpox. After a person has had chickenpox, the virus lies dormant in nerve tissue near the spinal cord and brain. Years later, it can reactivate as shingles. The rash typically appears as a single stripe of blisters on one side of the torso, but it can occur anywhere on the body. Early treatment can help shorten the infection and lessen the chance of complications, such as postherpetic neuralgia (long-lasting nerve pain).
symptoms: Pain, burning, numbness, or tingling, which often begins several days before the rash appears
A red rash that begins a few days after the pain
Fluid-filled blisters that break open and crust over
Itching
The rash usually affects a single dermatome (an area of skin supplied by a single spinal nerve) on one side of the body
Fever, headache, chills, and fatigue
prevention: The shingles vaccine (Shingrix) is highly effective at preventing shingles and its complications. It is recommended for adults 50 and older
The chickenpox vaccine (varicella vaccine) can prevent the initial infection that leads to shingles later in life
Maintaining a strong immune system through a healthy lifestyle
Avoid close contact with the open blisters of an infected individual if you have never had chickenpox or the vaccine
treatment: Prescription antiviral drugs, such as acyclovir, valacyclovir, and famciclovir, can speed healing and reduce the risk of complications (most effective when started within 72 hours of the rash appearing)
Pain relief medications, from over-the-counter NSAIDs to prescription pain relievers for severe pain
Topical treatments like calamine lotion and wet compresses to help relieve itching
Medications for nerve pain, such as gabapentin or amitriptyline, for postherpetic neuralgia

name: Sickle Cell Anemia
description: Sickle cell anemia is a serious, inherited blood disorder in which red blood cells, normally round, become crescent or 'sickle'-shaped. This change in shape is caused by an abnormal type of hemoglobin. These rigid, sticky cells can get stuck in small blood vessels, which can slow or block blood flow and oxygen to parts of the body. This blockage can cause episodes of severe pain (pain crises) and lead to complications like infections, acute chest syndrome, and stroke. It is a lifelong illness that is most common in people of African, Mediterranean, and South Asian descent.
symptoms: Anemia, leading to fatigue, pallor, and shortness of breath
Episodes of severe pain, known as pain crises, which can last for hours or days
Painful swelling of the hands and feet (dactylitis), often the first sign in babies
Frequent infections due to damage to the spleen
Delayed growth or puberty in children
Vision problems due to blocked blood vessels in the eyes
Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
prevention: As it is a genetic disorder, it cannot be prevented
Genetic counseling for individuals who carry the sickle cell trait can help them understand the risk of having a child with the disease
Newborn screening allows for early diagnosis and initiation of preventive treatments
Prophylactic penicillin in young children to prevent serious infections
treatment: There is no widely available cure; treatment focuses on managing symptoms and preventing complications
Pain management with over-the-counter or prescription pain medications
Hydroxyurea, a medication that can reduce the frequency of pain crises and the need for blood transfusions
Blood transfusions to treat and prevent complications like stroke
Folic acid supplements to help make new red blood cells
A bone marrow or stem cell transplant is the only potential cure but is a complex and risky procedure

name: Silicosis
description: Silicosis is a long-term, irreversible occupational lung disease caused by inhaling large amounts of crystalline silica dust over many years. Silica is a common mineral found in materials like sand, rock, and quartz. When workers cut, grind, or drill these materials, fine dust particles are released and can be inhaled deep into the lungs. This causes inflammation and scarring (fibrosis) in the lung tissue, which reduces the lungs' ability to function. It primarily affects workers in industries like mining, construction, and stonework. The damage is progressive and can lead to severe breathing problems.
symptoms: Early stages may have no symptoms
Persistent, severe cough, sometimes with phlegm
Progressive shortness of breath, especially during exercise
Chest pain and tightness
Fatigue and weakness
Fever and night sweats
Bluish skin (cyanosis) in advanced stages
prevention: Strictly an occupational disease, so prevention focuses on workplace safety
Use water sprays and ventilation systems to control and reduce dust at the source
Wear appropriate respiratory protective equipment, such as N95 respirators or more advanced masks
Practice good personal hygiene, like washing hands and face before eating or drinking
Regular health screenings and chest X-rays for exposed workers
treatment: There is no cure for silicosis, and the lung damage is irreversible
Treatment is supportive and aims to relieve symptoms and prevent complications
Stop all further exposure to silica dust immediately
Bronchodilators to open up airways
Oxygen therapy for advanced disease
Prompt treatment of any respiratory infections
A lung transplant may be an option in the most severe cases

name: Sinusitis
description: Sinusitis, or a sinus infection, is the inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses, which are hollow spaces within the bones between your eyes, behind your cheekbones, and in your forehead. When healthy, sinuses are filled with air, but when they become blocked and filled with fluid, germs (bacteria, viruses, or fungi) can grow and cause an infection. Common causes include the common cold, allergies (allergic rhinitis), or structural issues like a deviated septum. Acute sinusitis is short-term, while chronic sinusitis lasts for 12 weeks or more despite treatment attempts.
symptoms: Nasal congestion or a blocked, stuffy nose
Thick, yellow or greenish nasal discharge
Pain, tenderness, swelling, and pressure around the eyes, cheeks, nose, or forehead
Postnasal drip (mucus dripping down the throat)
Reduced sense of smell and taste
Headache, ear pain, and toothache
Cough, sore throat, and bad breath (halitosis)
prevention: Avoid upper respiratory infections by practicing good hygiene and avoiding sick people
Manage allergies effectively with antihistamines or other treatments
Avoid smoke and pollutants that can irritate nasal passages
Use a humidifier to keep the air moist at home
Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids to keep mucus thin
treatment: Saline nasal spray or irrigation to rinse nasal passages
Decongestants to reduce swelling (for short-term use only)
Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen
Nasal corticosteroid sprays to decrease inflammation
Antibiotics are prescribed only if a bacterial infection is suspected
In chronic cases, surgery may be needed to clear the sinuses

name: Skin Fungal Infection
description: Skin fungal infections, or dermatomycoses, are very common diseases caused by various types of fungi, including yeasts and dermatophytes. These infections thrive in warm, moist, and dark areas of the body. Common examples include athlete's foot (tinea pedis), jock itch (tinea cruris), and ringworm (tinea corporis). They are typically not life-threatening but can be uncomfortable and persistent. The hot and humid climate in India makes these infections particularly prevalent. They can spread through direct contact, from contaminated surfaces, or from animals.
symptoms: Itching, stinging, or burning sensation
A red, scaly, or flaky rash
The rash may be circular in shape (as in ringworm)
Cracking, splitting, or peeling skin, especially between the toes
Blisters or pustules
Discolored patches of skin
prevention: Keep skin clean and dry, especially in skin folds, the groin, and between the toes
Wear loose-fitting, breathable clothing made of cotton
Change socks and underwear daily, or more often if they become sweaty
Avoid walking barefoot in public areas like locker rooms, pools, and showers
Do not share personal items such as towels, clothing, or razors
treatment: Over-the-counter (OTC) antifungal creams, powders, or sprays containing clotrimazole, miconazole, or terbinafine
Prescription-strength topical or oral antifungal medications for more severe or persistent infections
Keep the affected area clean and dry throughout the treatment period
Continue treatment for the recommended duration, even if symptoms improve, to prevent recurrence

name: Sleep Apnea
description: Sleep apnea is a potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep. There are several types, but the most common is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which occurs when throat muscles relax and block the airway. These pauses in breathing (apneas) can happen hundreds of times a night, leading to a drop in blood oxygen levels and disrupting sleep. This results in poor sleep quality, significant daytime sleepiness, and can increase the risk of serious health problems like high blood pressure, heart attack, and stroke.
symptoms: Loud snoring, which is often more prominent in OSA
Episodes of stopped breathing during sleep, witnessed by another person
Gasping for air or choking during sleep
Waking up with a dry mouth or sore throat
Morning headache
Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)
Difficulty concentrating, irritability, and mood changes
prevention: Maintain a healthy weight, as obesity is a major risk factor
Avoid alcohol, tranquilizers, and sleeping pills, which can relax throat muscles
Quit smoking, as it can increase inflammation and fluid retention in the upper airway
Try sleeping on your side or stomach instead of your back to help keep the airway open
Treat nasal congestion, which can worsen symptoms
treatment: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) machine, which delivers air pressure through a mask to keep the airway open during sleep
Oral appliances or mouthpieces that position the jaw or tongue to keep the airway open
Lifestyle changes, such as weight loss and exercise
Surgery to remove excess tissue from the throat or reposition the jaw, in some cases

name: Sporotrichosis
description: Sporotrichosis is an infection caused by a fungus called Sporothrix. This fungus lives in soil, on plants like sphagnum moss, rose bushes, and hay. The infection occurs when the fungal spores enter the skin through a small cut or scrape, typically while gardening or handling contaminated plant matter. For this reason, it's often called 'rose gardener's disease.' The most common form affects the skin, causing nodules and ulcers that can spread along lymphatic channels. Rarely, it can be inhaled and cause a pulmonary infection.
symptoms: A small, painless red, pink, or purple bump (nodule) at the entry site, usually on the hand or arm
The initial bump slowly enlarges and may develop into an open sore or ulcer
Additional bumps or sores may appear in a line, moving up the arm or leg along a lymph node channel
In the rare pulmonary form: cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, and fever
prevention: Wear protective clothing, such as long sleeves and thick gloves, when handling soil, moss, or thorny plants like roses
Be cautious of and avoid skin injuries when working outdoors
Clean any scratches or wounds promptly with soap and water
Individuals with weakened immune systems should be particularly careful
treatment: For skin infections, a course of oral antifungal medication, such as itraconazole, for several months is the standard treatment
A saturated solution of potassium iodide (SSKI) is another effective, older treatment
Severe or disseminated infections may require intravenous antifungal medication, such as amphotericin B
Treatment is generally very effective if started early and completed

name: Stiff Person Syndrome
description: Stiff Person Syndrome (SPS) is a rare, progressive neurological disorder characterized by fluctuating muscle rigidity in the trunk and limbs and a heightened sensitivity to stimuli such as noise, touch, and emotional distress, which can set off painful muscle spasms. The condition is considered an autoimmune disorder, often associated with antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD). SPS can severely affect mobility, making it difficult to walk or perform daily tasks, and can lead to falls and injuries.
symptoms: Progressive muscle stiffness, particularly in the trunk (axial muscles) and abdomen
Painful and severe muscle spasms triggered by sudden movements, loud noises, or stress
An altered, stiff-legged gait and hunched-over posture
Chronic pain and discomfort
Heightened anxiety and phobias related to crossing open spaces (agoraphobia) due to fear of spasms and falls
prevention: There is no known way to prevent SPS
Early diagnosis and treatment can help manage symptoms and improve quality of life
Regular monitoring by a neurologist is essential
Stress management techniques may help reduce the frequency of spasms
Physical and occupational therapy to maintain mobility and prevent falls
treatment: Treatment is symptomatic and focuses on muscle relaxation and immune modulation
High-dose benzodiazepines, like diazepam, or muscle relaxants like baclofen, to relieve stiffness and spasms
Immunotherapy, such as intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasmapheresis, to modulate the autoimmune response
Physical therapy, massage, and aqua therapy to improve mobility and reduce pain
Pain management strategies

name: Stomach (Gastric) Cancer
description: Stomach cancer, or gastric cancer, is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lining of the stomach. The disease often develops slowly over many years. Major risk factors include chronic infection with Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) bacteria, a diet high in smoked, salty, or pickled foods, smoking, and a family history of the disease. Early-stage stomach cancer rarely causes symptoms, which is why it is often diagnosed at an advanced stage when treatment is more difficult and the prognosis is poorer.
symptoms: Early symptoms are often vague and can include indigestion, heartburn, and bloating
Persistent abdominal pain or discomfort
Nausea, vomiting (sometimes with blood)
Feeling full after eating only a small amount of food (early satiety)
Unexplained weight loss and loss of appetite
Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
Weakness, fatigue, and black, tarry stools (melena) from bleeding
prevention: Treat H. pylori infection with antibiotics if detected
Eat a diet rich in fresh fruits and vegetables and low in salt, smoked, and pickled foods
Avoid smoking and limit alcohol consumption
Maintain a healthy weight through diet and exercise
Regular screening for individuals at high risk (e.g., strong family history)
treatment: Treatment depends on the stage of the cancer
Surgery (gastrectomy) to remove part or all of the stomach is the primary treatment for early-stage cancer
Chemotherapy, either before or after surgery, to shrink the tumor or kill remaining cancer cells
Radiation therapy, often used in combination with chemotherapy
Targeted drug therapy and immunotherapy for advanced stomach cancer

name: Stroke
description: A stroke, sometimes called a brain attack, is a medical emergency that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or severely reduced. This deprives brain tissue of essential oxygen and nutrients, causing brain cells to begin to die within minutes. There are two main types: an ischemic stroke, caused by a blocked artery (blood clot), and a hemorrhagic stroke, caused by a leaking or bursting blood vessel. Prompt treatment is crucial to minimize brain damage and potential complications.
symptoms: Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body
Sudden confusion, trouble speaking, or difficulty understanding speech (aphasia)
Sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance, or lack of coordination
Sudden severe headache with no known cause (often associated with hemorrhagic stroke)
Use the F.A.S.T. acronym: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call emergency services
prevention: Control high blood pressure (hypertension), the leading cause of stroke
Manage diabetes and high cholesterol
Do not smoke and limit alcohol consumption
Maintain a healthy diet low in saturated fat and sodium
Engage in regular physical activity
Maintain a healthy weight
Treat conditions like atrial fibrillation that increase clot formation risk
treatment: Immediate emergency medical care is critical
For ischemic stroke: Clot-busting medications (thrombolytics) like alteplase (tPA) given within a few hours of symptom onset, or mechanical thrombectomy to remove the clot
For hemorrhagic stroke: Procedures to control bleeding, reduce pressure on the brain, and repair the blood vessel
Post-stroke rehabilitation, including physical, occupational, and speech therapy, is vital for recovery

name: Strongyloidiasis
description: Strongyloidiasis is an intestinal infection caused by a parasitic roundworm, Strongyloides stercoralis. The infection begins when larvae from contaminated soil penetrate human skin. They then travel through the bloodstream to the lungs, are coughed up, swallowed, and finally mature in the small intestine. Unlike other worms, Strongyloides can replicate within the host, leading to a long-lasting (chronic) infection. In individuals with weakened immune systems, this can lead to a life-threatening hyperinfection syndrome.
symptoms: Many people with chronic infection are asymptomatic
Abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, and intermittent diarrhea and constipation
An itchy, red rash at the site of larval penetration (ground itch) or a linear rash on the buttocks and waist (larva currens)
A dry cough or throat irritation as larvae pass through the lungs
Unexplained weight loss and chronic fatigue
prevention: Wear shoes and protective footwear when walking on soil in endemic areas
Improve sanitation and hygiene to prevent fecal contamination of soil
Avoid direct contact with soil or sand that may be contaminated with human waste
Screening and treatment for individuals from endemic areas, especially before starting immunosuppressive therapy
treatment: Anti-parasitic medications are effective
Ivermectin is the drug of choice for treating both acute and chronic strongyloidiasis
Albendazole is an alternative treatment option
Treatment is crucial for immunocompromised individuals to prevent hyperinfection syndrome

name: Syphilis
description: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It progresses in distinct stages—primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary—each with different signs and symptoms. The infection is spread through direct contact with a syphilitic sore (chancre) during sexual activity. If left untreated, syphilis can cause serious and irreversible damage to the brain, nerves, eyes, heart, blood vessels, liver, bones, and joints. It can also be passed from a mother to her unborn child (congenital syphilis).
symptoms: Primary stage: A single, firm, painless, round sore (chancre) at the site of infection
Secondary stage: A non-itchy skin rash (often on palms and soles), swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, and fatigue
Latent stage: No visible signs or symptoms, but the infection remains in the body
Tertiary stage: Severe medical problems affecting the heart, brain, and other organs, which can appear years or decades after the initial infection
prevention: Practice safe sex by consistently and correctly using condoms
Limit the number of sexual partners and avoid sexual contact with anyone who has symptoms
Get regular STI screening, especially if you have multiple partners or are in a high-risk group
Abstain from sexual contact until you and your partner have been tested and treated
treatment: Syphilis is easily curable in its early stages with antibiotics
Penicillin, administered as an injection, is the preferred treatment for all stages
A single injection is usually sufficient for early-stage syphilis, while later stages require multiple doses
It is crucial for all sexual partners to be notified, tested, and treated
Follow-up blood tests are needed to ensure the infection has been cured

name: Takayasu Arteritis
description: Takayasu arteritis is a rare type of vasculitis, a group of disorders that cause inflammation of blood vessels. It primarily damages the aorta—the large artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body—and its main branches. The inflammation can lead to narrowing (stenosis), blockage, or weakening (aneurysm) of the arteries, which can reduce blood flow to various parts of the body. It most often affects young women and teenage girls, and is sometimes called 'pulseless disease' because it can cause a weak or absent pulse in the arms.
symptoms: Early stage: Fatigue, unintended weight loss, fever, muscle and joint pain
Late stage: Arm or leg weakness and pain with use (claudication), dizziness or fainting, headaches, vision problems
High blood pressure
A difference in blood pressure between the arms
A weak or absent pulse in the arms, legs, or neck
Chest pain or shortness of breath
prevention: There is no known way to prevent Takayasu arteritis as the cause is unknown
Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing irreversible artery damage
Regular monitoring of blood pressure and imaging tests to check for artery damage
Maintaining a healthy lifestyle and managing cardiovascular risk factors
treatment: Treatment aims to control inflammation and prevent further damage to blood vessels
Corticosteroids, like prednisone, are the first-line treatment to reduce inflammation
Immunosuppressant drugs, such as methotrexate or azathioprine, are used to help taper off steroids
Biologic medications that target specific inflammatory pathways
Surgical procedures, such as bypass grafting or angioplasty, to treat narrowed or blocked arteries

name: Tay-Sachs Disease
description: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare, fatal genetic disorder caused by the absence of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A (Hex-A). Without this enzyme, a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside accumulates to toxic levels in the brain and spinal cord, progressively destroying nerve cells. The most common form appears in infancy. An apparently healthy baby begins to show symptoms around 6 months of age, followed by a relentless deterioration of mental and physical abilities, leading to death in early childhood. It is an autosomal recessive disorder, meaning a child must inherit two copies of the defective gene, one from each parent, to have the disease.
symptoms: Loss of motor skills, such as turning over, sitting, and crawling
An exaggerated startle response to loud noises
A cherry-red spot in the eye, visible during an eye exam
Progressive muscle weakness leading to paralysis
Seizures
Vision and hearing loss, leading to blindness and deafness
Intellectual disability and eventual loss of responsiveness
prevention: The disease cannot be prevented in an affected individual, but its incidence can be reduced through genetic screening
Carrier screening for individuals in high-risk populations (such as those of Ashkenazi Jewish descent) to identify if they carry the defective gene
Genetic counseling for carrier couples to discuss options like prenatal testing or in vitro fertilization with preimplantation genetic diagnosis
treatment: There is no cure for Tay-Sachs disease
Treatment is supportive and palliative, focusing on managing symptoms and providing comfort
Anticonvulsant medications to control seizures
Nutritional support, often requiring a feeding tube, to prevent choking and ensure hydration
Physical therapy to relieve muscle spasticity
Respiratory care to manage mucus buildup in the lungs

name: Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis)
description: Tennis elbow, or lateral epicondylitis, is a common overuse injury that causes pain on the outer part of the elbow. It occurs when the tendons that connect the forearm muscles to the outside of the elbow (the lateral epicondyle) become inflamed and develop tiny tears. Despite its name, it affects not only tennis players but also anyone who performs repetitive gripping activities with their wrist and arm, such as painters, carpenters, and plumbers. The pain is often a dull ache that can become a sharp pain when performing certain movements.
symptoms: Pain and tenderness on the bony knob on the outside of the elbow
Pain that radiates from the outside of the elbow down to the forearm and wrist
Weak grip strength
Pain that worsens when shaking hands, turning a doorknob, or holding a coffee cup
Pain during wrist extension or lifting objects
prevention: Use proper technique and appropriately sized equipment in sports
Warm up before and stretch after activities involving the arm
Strengthen the forearm muscles with specific exercises
Avoid overuse and take regular breaks from repetitive tasks
Wear a counterforce brace on the forearm to reduce tendon strain
treatment: Resting the affected arm and modifying activities that cause pain
Applying ice packs to the elbow to reduce inflammation
Over-the-counter pain relievers (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen
Physical therapy to stretch and strengthen the forearm muscles
Using a forearm strap or brace to reduce stress on the tendon
Corticosteroid injections for short-term pain relief
Surgery is rarely needed and is considered only after conservative treatments fail

name: Tetanus
description: Tetanus, also known as lockjaw, is a serious but preventable bacterial infection that affects the nervous system. It is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, whose spores are found everywhere in the environment, particularly in soil, dust, and manure. The bacteria can enter the body through any break in the skin, such as a cut, puncture wound, or burn. Once inside, they produce a powerful toxin (tetanospasmin) that interferes with nerves controlling muscles, leading to severe muscle stiffness and spasms. It is a medical emergency that can be fatal.
symptoms: Stiffness and spasms in the jaw muscles (lockjaw), making it difficult to open the mouth or swallow
Stiffness of the neck, abdominal, and back muscles
Painful, involuntary muscle spasms throughout the body, which can be strong enough to cause bone fractures
Sudden, painful spasms often triggered by minor events, like a loud noise or a light touch
Fever, sweating, and rapid heart rate
prevention: Vaccination is the best way to prevent tetanus
The tetanus vaccine is part of the routine childhood immunization series (DTaP) and requires booster shots (Tdap or Td) every 10 years for adults
Proper and immediate care for all wounds, no matter how minor. Clean wounds thoroughly with soap and water
A tetanus booster shot may be recommended after an injury, depending on the wound and vaccination history
treatment: Hospitalization is required for treatment
Administration of Tetanus immune globulin (TIG) to neutralize the toxin that has not yet bound to nerve tissue
A course of the tetanus vaccine to develop future immunity
Antibiotics to kill the Clostridium tetani bacteria
Muscle relaxants and sedatives to control muscle spasms
Supportive care, possibly including a ventilator to assist with breathing

name: Thalassemia
description: Thalassemia is a group of inherited blood disorders that affect the body's ability to produce hemoglobin, the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. This leads to a shortage of healthy red blood cells and a lack of oxygen in the bloodstream, resulting in anemia. The severity of the disease depends on the number of gene mutations inherited. Mild forms (thalassemia minor) may not require treatment, while severe forms (thalassemia major) require lifelong medical care, including regular blood transfusions.
symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath due to anemia
Pale or yellowish skin (jaundice)
Slow growth and delayed puberty in children
Bone deformities, especially in the face, due to expansion of the bone marrow
Dark urine
Enlarged spleen, liver, or heart
prevention: As a genetic disorder, it cannot be prevented in an affected individual
Genetic counseling and carrier screening for couples before pregnancy, especially in high-risk populations, to understand the chances of having a child with thalassemia
Premarital screening can help identify carriers
Prenatal testing can diagnose thalassemia in an unborn baby
treatment: Treatment depends on the type and severity
Frequent blood transfusions (every few weeks) are the main treatment for thalassemia major to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels
Iron chelation therapy to remove the excess iron from the body that builds up from repeated transfusions
Folic acid supplements to support red blood cell production
A bone marrow or stem cell transplant is the only potential cure, typically performed in children

name: Thyroid Disorder
description: Thyroid disorders are conditions that affect the thyroid gland, a butterfly-shaped gland in the front of the neck. The thyroid produces hormones that regulate the body's metabolism, controlling how the body uses energy. The two main types of thyroid disorders are hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid), where the gland doesn't produce enough hormones, and hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), where it produces too much. These imbalances can affect everything from heart rate and body temperature to weight and mood. Thyroid issues are very common worldwide, especially among women.
symptoms: Unexplained changes in weight (gain in hypothyroidism, loss in hyperthyroidism)
Persistent fatigue and changes in energy levels
Hair loss or changes in hair texture
Mood swings, anxiety, nervousness (hyperthyroidism) or depression (hypothyroidism)
Feeling too cold (hypothyroidism) or too hot (hyperthyroidism)
Changes in heart rate (slow in hypo-, fast in hyperthyroidism)
A visible swelling in the neck (goiter)
prevention: Ensure adequate dietary intake of iodine, which is essential for thyroid hormone production (iodized salt is a common source)
Regular thyroid function tests, especially for those with a family history or autoimmune conditions
Manage stress, as it can impact hormonal balance
Avoid smoking, which can affect thyroid function
treatment: Hypothyroidism is treated with daily hormone replacement medication (levothyroxine)
Hyperthyroidism treatment includes anti-thyroid medications, radioactive iodine therapy to shrink the gland, or surgery (thyroidectomy) in some cases
Beta-blockers can be used to manage symptoms like rapid heart rate in hyperthyroidism
Regular monitoring of thyroid hormone levels is essential to adjust medication dosages

name: Thyroid Disorder (Hypothyroidism)
description: Hypothyroidism, or underactive thyroid, is a common endocrine condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough crucial thyroid hormones. Since these hormones regulate metabolism, a deficiency can cause many of the body's functions to slow down. The most common cause worldwide is iodine deficiency, but in iodine-sufficient regions, it is most often caused by an autoimmune disease called Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is more common in women and its prevalence increases with age. Treatment is usually lifelong but effective in managing symptoms.
symptoms: Persistent fatigue, lethargy, and increased need for sleep
Unexplained weight gain and difficulty losing weight
Dry, coarse skin and thinning hair or hair loss
Intolerance to cold
Constipation
Muscle aches, tenderness, and stiffness
Depression, impaired memory, and difficulty concentrating ('brain fog')
A slowed heart rate
prevention: Ensuring an adequate intake of iodine through diet (e.g., using iodized salt)
There is no way to prevent autoimmune Hashimoto's disease
Regular health checkups and blood tests for those at high risk (e.g., family history, other autoimmune diseases)
Avoid excessive intake of certain foods (goitrogens) in their raw state if you have an iodine deficiency
treatment: Standard treatment is daily oral thyroid hormone replacement therapy with levothyroxine
The medication restores adequate hormone levels, reversing the signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism
Dosage is carefully adjusted based on regular blood tests (TSH levels)
It is a lifelong treatment, and medication should be taken consistently as prescribed
Maintaining a balanced diet and healthy lifestyle supports overall well-being

name: Thyroid Disorders
description: Thyroid disorders are medical conditions that prevent the thyroid gland from producing the right amount of hormones. The thyroid gland can be overactive (hyperthyroidism) or underactive (hypothyroidism). Hyperthyroidism speeds up metabolism, causing weight loss and a rapid heartbeat. Hypothyroidism slows down metabolism, leading to weight gain and fatigue. Causes can include autoimmune diseases (Graves' disease for hyper, Hashimoto's for hypo), iodine deficiency, inflammation, or nodules. These disorders are prevalent in India, significantly impacting quality of life if left unmanaged.
symptoms: Significant, unintended weight changes (loss with hyper-, gain with hypo-)
Chronic fatigue or, conversely, hyperactivity and nervousness
Hair loss, dry skin, and brittle nails
Mood swings, anxiety, irritability, or depression
Sensitivity to heat (hyperthyroidism) or cold (hypothyroidism)
Irregular menstrual periods
Goiter (enlargement of the thyroid gland)
prevention: Consume a balanced diet with sufficient iodine
Regular screening, especially if there is a family history of thyroid or autoimmune diseases
Manage stress through techniques like yoga or meditation
Avoid smoking and excessive alcohol consumption
treatment: For hypothyroidism: Daily thyroid hormone replacement pills (levothyroxine)
For hyperthyroidism: Antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine therapy, or surgery
Beta-blockers to control symptoms like rapid heart rate
Regular monitoring of hormone levels via blood tests to ensure proper medication dosage

name: Tonsillitis
description: Tonsillitis is the inflammation of the tonsils, which are two oval-shaped pads of tissue at the back of the throat, one on each side. They are part of the body's immune system, acting as a first line of defense against pathogens entering through the mouth. Tonsillitis is most often caused by common viruses, but bacterial infections, such as streptococcus (strep throat), can also be a cause. It is very common in children but can occur at any age. While most cases resolve on their own or with simple treatment, recurrent or severe cases can cause complications.
symptoms: A very sore throat
Red, swollen tonsils, sometimes with white or yellow patches or coating (pus)
Pain or difficulty when swallowing
Fever and chills
Swollen, tender lymph nodes in the neck
A scratchy or muffled voice
Headache and bad breath
prevention: Practice good hygiene, especially frequent and thorough handwashing
Avoid sharing food, drinks, utensils, or toothbrushes
Stay away from or limit contact with people who are sick with a sore throat or cold
Cover your mouth when you cough or sneeze
treatment: Home care: Get plenty of rest, drink warm fluids, and eat soft foods
Gargle with warm salt water to soothe the throat
Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen to reduce pain and fever
Antibiotics are prescribed only for bacterial tonsillitis (strep throat) and the full course must be completed
Surgery to remove the tonsils (tonsillectomy) may be considered for frequent, recurrent, or severe tonsillitis

name: Trichomoniasis
description: Trichomoniasis (or 'trich') is a very common sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by a single-celled protozoan parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. The infection is spread through sexual contact. While the infection is common, many people, especially men, do not have any symptoms. When symptoms do occur, they can range from mild irritation to severe inflammation. It is important to treat trichomoniasis as it can increase the risk of getting or spreading other STIs, including HIV, and can cause complications in pregnant women.
symptoms: Many people have no symptoms

In women: Itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals; discomfort with urination; and a thin discharge with an unusual smell that can be clear, white, yellowish, or greenish (frothy discharge)
In men: Itching or irritation inside the penis; burning after urination or ejaculation; and some discharge from the penis
prevention: The most reliable way to prevent infection is to abstain from sexual activity or to be in a long-term, mutually monogamous relationship with a partner who has been tested and is known to be uninfected
Consistent and correct use of latex condoms can reduce the risk of transmission
Regular STI checkups
Avoiding the sharing of sex toys
treatment: Trichomoniasis is curable with antibiotics
The most common treatment is a single, large dose of either metronidazole or tinidazole
It is crucial that all sexual partners are treated at the same time to prevent reinfection
Abstain from sexual contact until the infection is cured in both you and your partner (about a week after treatment)

name: Tuberculosis (TB)
description: Tuberculosis (TB) is a serious infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs (pulmonary TB) but can also attack other parts of the body, such as the kidney, spine, and brain (extrapulmonary TB). TB is spread through the air when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or speaks, releasing TB bacteria into the air. Not everyone infected with TB bacteria becomes sick; some have a latent TB infection. If not treated properly, active TB disease can be fatal. India has the highest burden of TB globally.
symptoms: A persistent cough that lasts for three weeks or longer
Coughing up blood or sputum (phlegm from deep inside the lungs)
Chest pain, or pain with breathing or coughing
Unintentional weight loss and loss of appetite
Fatigue, fever, and night sweats
prevention: The Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine is given to infants in countries with high TB prevalence, like India, to prevent severe forms of childhood TB
Avoid prolonged close contact with people who have active TB disease
Ensure good ventilation in living and working spaces
Treatment of latent TB infection to prevent it from becoming active TB disease
treatment: TB is curable with a specific course of antibiotics
Treatment for active TB involves taking a combination of several drugs for at least 6 to 9 months
It is crucial to complete the entire course of medication as prescribed to prevent the development of drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB)
Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) programs are used to ensure patients take their medication correctly

name: Tularemia
description: Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever or deer fly fever, is a rare but potentially serious infectious disease caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. Humans can become infected through various routes, including tick and deer fly bites, handling infected animal carcasses (like rabbits or rodents), consuming contaminated food or water, or inhaling airborne bacteria. It is not known to be transmitted from person to person. The disease can cause a range of symptoms depending on how the bacteria enter the body and can be fatal if not treated with appropriate antibiotics.
symptoms: Symptoms vary depending on the route of exposure
Ulceroglandular (most common): A skin ulcer at the site of infection and swollen, painful lymph glands
Glandular: Swollen lymph glands without a skin ulcer
Oculoglandular: Eye irritation, pain, swelling, and discharge
Pneumonic: Cough, chest pain, and difficulty breathing (most serious form)
Sudden fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches are common to all forms
prevention: Use insect repellent containing DEET to prevent tick and fly bites
Wear gloves and protective eyewear when handling or skinning animals, especially rabbits and rodents
Cook game meat thoroughly before eating
Avoid drinking water from untreated sources like streams or lakes
Avoid mowing over dead animals, which can aerosolize the bacteria
treatment: Tularemia can be effectively treated with antibiotics
Injectable antibiotics like streptomycin or gentamicin are typically used for severe disease
Oral antibiotics such as doxycycline or ciprofloxacin may be used for less serious cases
Prompt treatment is important to prevent serious complications

name: Tularenic Pneumonia
description: Tularenic pneumonia is the most severe and life-threatening form of tularemia, an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. This form of the disease occurs when the bacteria are inhaled, or when they spread to the lungs through the bloodstream from another site of infection. It can result from activities like landscaping, farming, or laboratory exposure. Without prompt diagnosis and aggressive antibiotic treatment, tularenic pneumonia has a high mortality rate.
